**Pine Creek Residential School**
October 1, 1938 to April 30, 1939 ...... $40.00 a month

**Sandy Bay Residential School**
October 1, 1938 to April 30, 1939 ...... $40.00 a month

**Portage la Prairie Residential School**

Ottawa, October 29, 1938.

Mr. Philip Phelan,
Chief Welfare & Training,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ont.

My dear Mr. Phelan:

In the spring of 1936, your Department supplied a Chevrolet utility truck to the Pine Creek Indian Residential school. You are aware, no doubt, that the school is forty-five miles from the nearest railroad point and the use of a truck is essential for the hauling of the school supplies. When the request for this truck was made, your Department had no hesitation in supplying it as it readily admitted its necessity.

The truck has now done three seasons. The mileage according to the last information received from the Principal is 28,605 miles. The truck is not at the present time in very good running condition and the Principal is informed by the Chevrolet Service Station at Dauphin, Manitoba, that necessary repairs and replacements would cost about $200.00, and that also a new set of tires would be required.

In view of the above, the Principal would like to be authorized to exchange the truck for a new one. The local agent has offered the sum of $600.00, for the truck on condition, of course, that a new one be bought from him.

I hope that you will be able to meet the wishes of the Principal in this matter.

Yours very truly,

J. O. Plourde, O. M. I.

Mr. R. A. Hoey,

My dear Mr. Hoey:

I am in receipt of a letter from Rev. Fr. Ruest, principal of the Pine Creek Indian Residential School, in which he informs me that the electrical plant both engine and dynamo must be overhauled as soon as possible.

The Mumford Medland Co. of Winnipeg have tendered $677.00 for this work. That price does not include transportation of the plant from Pine Creek to Winnipeg and return. As the school is about forty miles from the railroad station and as the distance by rail is about two hundred and sixty miles it is estimated that the total return freight charges would be at least $100.00.

Under the circumstances it has been suggested that instead of having the old plant repaired a new one might be purchased. The extra cost would not be very much and would be easily made up by the absence of repairs within the next eight or ten years. It is generally admitted that the diesel engines are not only more economical to operate but also last longer. A plant similar to the one now being installed at Sandy Bay would answer the purpose.

Would it be possible for your Mr. Hamilton to get in touch with the Mumford Medland Co. of Winnipeg and ask their advice on this matter and also secure prices on a new plant as well as on repairs to the existing one.

Knowing as you do how important a lighting plant is in a residential school, I hope that you will be able to attend to this matter at your earliest convenience.

Yours very truly,

J. O. Plourde, O.M.I.

Dear Sir:

I wish to acknowledge your letter No. 126-1-5, dated February 24th, and enclose for your information copies of correspondence re the lighting plant at the Pine Creek Indian Residential School.

The present plant is in poor condition and undoubtedly the repair bill will be quite high. In addition, the engine operates by gasoline and, as noted by the enclosed correspondence, costs about $275.00 per year for fuel.

You will note several options are given by Mumford, Medland, Limited.

No. 1 - That the present engine be replaced by a new gasoline engine at a cost of $300.00
Freight charges, approximately $100.00
Reconstruction of Switch-Board $81.00
Total $481.00

No. 2 - Replacing the present engine with 10 H.P. Lister Diesel, changing switch board to semi-automatic
Freight, approximately $667.00
Total $767.00

No. 3 - Supplying a complete new unit, as per attached quotation addressed to Father Lamontagne and dated March 1st,
Freight charges, approximately $833.00
Less allowance on old 6 K.W. generator $50.00
Total $833.00

The No. 1 offer is $400.00 less than No. 3. Dear Sir:

Re: Pine Creek Indian Residential School, Manitoba.

In accordance with your request, the writer visited the Pine Creek Residential School and made an examination of the same on April 25th and 26th.

The main building, 111' x 50', with solid masonry walls, was erected about thirty years ago. It consists of basement and three stories with attic. The structure was erected by the Oblate Fathers Order and there is no record of any plan of the building being retained. There has been alterations throughout the years but no plans were made of the same except in connection with the drains from the building.

The stone masonry walls of the building are in very good condition, the only cracks of importance being on either side of the southern wall. These cracks do not account for any of the trouble experienced with the settlement of the floors, nor do they at present affect the stability of the walls. There are minor cracks in the vicinity of the windows but these also are of little importance at present.

The basement floor would appear to be about four feet below the grade and is of concrete construction. The boiler room floor is also of concrete and about eight feet below grade. The other floors are all of wooden construction with plastered ceilings and walls. The attic is unfinished. The floors are supported by six beams extending across the building at 15-foot centres. The floor joists run lengthwise of the building on these beams and support the floor. On all three floors the beams appear to be directly over one another. Some beams extend below the ceiling but have been boxed in to present the appearance of being arched and the type of construction could not be ascertained without doing considerable damage to the existing condition.

The unfinished ceiling over the boiler room afforded an opportunity of examining the nature of the beams and joists but without tearing up the floor, it was not possible to examine the method of construction elsewhere except in the attic. It would appear, however, that the beams and joists are all made of planking sawn locally at the time of the construction. This planking varied from 2½" to 3½" in thickness and from 8 to 10 inches in width. The beams exposed over the boilers were built up of three pieces of planking, the planking standing on edge to give a beam size of 9' x 10'. The ends of the beams were imbedded in the masonry walls. The joists were also 2½" to 3½" thick and about ten inches deep and were spaced about every two feet. However, it was noticed that some of these joists did not extend from beam support to beam support but were spliced. The planking was not bolted in making the beam but simply nailed and it was noticed that where one beam was spliced to another beam, two long bolts were the only fastening. However, at this particular junction, a log up-right had been placed to support this connection.

M.T.S. Mills, Esq.,
Chief Engineer,
Engineering and Construction Service,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Indian Affairs. (RG 1C, Volume 6271, file 582-5, part 5)
is altogether probable that the floor construction became lighter in the upper storeys.

The partitions appear to have been erected without any consideration being given to having the weight of the same properly supported - even the hallways are not directly over one another. Apparently, the central hallway partitions are required to support the six main cross beams forming part of each of the three floors. In the basement, however, the cross beams are each supported by four upright iron supports, two on either side of each of the partitions. These uprights rest on the concrete floor but whether or not there is any footing below the concrete floor was not determined. The only uprights in the first floor supporting the cross beams were two in each of the two classrooms. Examination showed that these had been placed when partitions had been removed. In the second storey there were uprights in the chapel, in the northeast corner of the floor; two uprights being placed under each of the three beams that crossed the ceiling. The only other upright was one recently placed to support the third beam from the northerly end of the building. In the third floor or dormitories, there were no individual upright supports. The two partitions separating the Girls and Boys' Dormitories, were placed directly over the third and fourth cross beams and evidently a considerable weight of the roof has to be carried by these two partitions. These two partitions were also fairly heavily loaded with wash basins, bath-tubs, water pipes and toilets and at times would have to carry a concentrated load of many children using the common toilet. The stair-ways from the dormitories to the main floor, are in the northeast and southeast corners and between the outer walls and the first cross beam from either wall. Whether or not extra joists were placed to support the stairways could not be ascertained without tearing up the floor but there were no uprights placed except one very recently. These stairways appear to be insufficiently supported on every landing.

The situation at this school is that there has been a decided sinking of the floors in the northeast section and also in the central easterly section. Everywhere the floors slope inwardly from the main walls of the building; the floors are very uneven, cracking of partitions is much in evidence, doors jam and continually need cutting or additions, radiators tilt; the plumbing gets out of line and in some sections it would appear that structural weaknesses exist, even to the extent of possibly being dangerous. It is quite noticeable that the westerly half of the building shows little of the serious structural weaknesses that have developed in the easterly section. The most noticeable defects have occurred in the northeasterly corner and extend from the attic to the boiler room. The sinking is especially noticeable in the Boys' Dormitory. Another very noticeable defect has developed in the easterly section from the attic to basement in the central portion under the third and fourth cross beams. It would appear as if not only the cross beams have sagged from insufficient support but that the joists have also sagged between cross beams from the heavy partitions and etc. The school authorities claim that the conditions outlined above are continuously growing more serious. The boiler room is in the northeast corner of the building and a support has been placed under the first cross beam and resting upon the top of the furnace.
The writer is of the opinion that it will be necessary to provide supports for all beams in the building from basement to attic. It is essential that proper footings under the basement floor should be provided for four uprights under each of the six cross beams and such uprights should be placed directly above one another on each floor to the dormitory ceiling. Undoubtedly, some of these uprights will hit into existing partitions, class rooms, bedrooms, bathrooms, toilets and etc., at most inconvenient locations. This may necessitate some of the beams being replaced by I beams or girders. Many joists may have to be cut to an extent requiring their replacement. To make repairs would involve tearing up floors. To place uprights, partitions would have to be exposed.

The present stairways should be condemned and replaced with fire-proof stairways. An additional fire escape should be provided for each of the two dormitories. It will be necessary to drain around the boiler-room section of the building to prevent seepage into the boiler room, also to provide a drainage ditch under the boiler by means of sump and pumping equipment. The boilers will probably have to be dismantled, proper foundations be provided and the boilers rebuilt. Relining of the boilers should also be carried out at the same time. The radiators, plumbing and etc. will have to be realigned. The masonry walls in the northeast corner of the building, which are not in any dangerous condition, should be underpinned in order to close the cracks. Examination of the roof showed this part of the structure to be in good condition, except that some leakage occurs around the chimneys, ventilators and at the bracing of the belfry. It would be advisable to endeavour to seal these connections and also to give the roof a coat of weather-proofing paint.

The writer has discussed the situation at this school with Mr. Waite, Indian Agent at Portage la Prairie, who has visited the school and reported upon the same. The situation at the school has also been explained to Mr. Parkinson, Resident Architect, Department of Public Works, Winnipeg. From these discussions, we have decided that it is impossible to give any estimate of the probable cost of the work that would be involved in supporting the floors of this building. The simplest and cheapest method of support, namely, steel uprights under all beams, involves so much cutting up of partitions, floors, ceilings and etc., that much additional work, redecorating and etc., would be required. It is impossible to estimate at present what limitation could be placed upon the repair work. Mr. Parkinson stated that the wooden stairways to the children's dormitories, should by all means be condemned and replaced by fire-proof stairways and also that two additional fire escapes should be provided. Mr. Waite had no suggestions to make with respect to the fire-proof stairways or additional fire escapes, but appeared to be of the opinion that the whole floor structure of beams and joists might need to be replaced if fire-proof stairways are provided, also additional fire escapes, and the floors are supported by steel uprights throughout and the boilers properly supported, a minimum outlay of $15,000 is involved and the final cost might easily amount to $25,000 or $35,000.00.
The cost of levelling up the floors of this building and lessening the hazard in case of fire, is of an amount that would appear to warrant a thorough examination of the building by a responsible official of the Architect's Division of the Engineering and Construction Service at Ottawa. A preliminary to the carrying out of any repair work would be a survey of this school in order to prepare plans of the structure as it now exists and also detailed plans of the floors and partitions.

Yours truly,

(sgd) D.B. Gow,
District Chief Engineer.

Dear Sir:

Winnipeg, August 12th, 1939.

Dear Sir:

Re: Pine Creek Indian School,
Camperville, Man.

Replying to your letter of August 11th, reference to proposed immediate necessary repairs to the above school, the subject was discussed today with Mr. Desrosiers and Father La Montagne, unfortunately Mr. Cow being out of town was unable to be present, however, he was later reached by telephone and informed of the discussions.

The immediate repairs for this year, are the replacement of ten wrought iron columns and the jacking up of the floors, where columns are to be introduced.

Mr. Desrosiers was advised that $3,000.00 was too high for this amount of work, and has submitted the enclosed estimate of $2,000.00, which I consider fair and reasonable, taking into consideration, the transportation of materials from the rail head at Winnipegosis.

The work proposed for the present year, may be executed whilst the school is in session, there should be little or no interference with studies and the building will be perfectly safe at all times.

During the year 1940, an appropriation large enough to rebuild with fireproof materials two stairways, take down brickwork to two boilers, stop the underground spring and rebuild brickwork, is recommended.

The fireproofing of the ceiling of the boiler room is advisable, also the removal of wood partition to boiler room stair. An increase of windows to stairways is recommended, some parts are in total darkness.

At the time of inspection I was impressed with the excellent maintenance of the building; The Engineer in charge of the plant has devised many splendid mechanical improvements and the whole of the engineering equipment is very well attended.

From today I shall be away from this office for three weeks, in the meantime Mr. G. Ritchie of this department will be pleased to render any further assistance regarding the subject of the school repair.

Dear Sir,

I have just received a letter from the Rev. Father Ruest, principal of the Pine Creek Indian Residential School and quote the following -

"You would remember, as I do that on this occasion, you and Mr. Waite have kindly agreed on the necessity of a new kitchen stove for our school. The actual one being really too small and wear out. We have hoped that some days would have brought us the agreeable surprise of a new range. A year had passed, time and fire have continued their work on the old stove. The cooking top of the old unit is completely ruined and falling in pieces."

I would refer the Department to my report dated November 18, 1938, to the last paragraph on the second page, in which I pointed out that the stove had been repaired several times and that I considered it unsafe as it has burned through in several places.

I would recommend that, if possible, a new stove be provided, as I am quite sure another year of constant use, would not improve the condition of the range and I am inclined to think Father Ruest's request is justifiable. He requests that the range have three ovens and two fire boxes.

Yours very truly,

WINNIPEG, April 4, 1940

Ottawa

My dear Mr. Phelan:

I am enclosing the following invoices regarding the special repairs authorized last August for the Pine Creek Indian Res. School:

- Workmen's Compensation Board........$34.24
- Camperville Freighters..............2.87
- Dominion Bridge Company Ltd........52.00
- Toupin Lumber & Fuel Co. Ltd........8.67

The above invoices and Labour Returns complete the balance of the work that had to be done at the above School. I gather from figures submitted to me by our Superintendent, that the total cost of these repairs was $1,887.50. I am informed that all this work was done in a satisfactory manner and that all danger of the floor collapsing has been removed.

Repairs to the boiler room remain to be done, but I understand that funds may be provided for this purpose. I think it would be advisable for your architect to make a further study of this boiler room problem and to report on it.

Dear Sirs:

We have now received the statement of actual payroll had by the Oblate Fathers, Pine Creek Indian Reservation School during the present year 1940.

We have adjusted their assessment based upon this statement of actual payroll and Notice of Assessment was handed to these people at a recent date. It is our understanding that this Notice of Assessment will in turn be forwarded to you for your attention. We have been advised that payment in settlement of this assessment will be furnished by you to this Board.

We would point out as well, that the assessment of the Oblate Fathers in respect of the Indian Residential School at Sandy Bay which called for payment of $365.54, has gone forward to you at a previous date.

There is now due to this Board therefore, two remittances in the amounts of $34.24 and $365.54. Would you please let us have your advice as to when we may expect to receive payment of these assessments.

As the boiler room is in the school itself and is not fireproof, and furthermore as there is a hidden well which is causing considerable trouble every year and which has already undermined the concrete floor and caused the heaving of the boiler brick work, and as it is thought that it would be very difficult to divert the artesian well under the flooring, both our Mr. Desrosiers and your architect are of the opinion that instead of carrying out the repairs mentioned above it would be preferable to build a fireproof boiler room outside of the school but close enough to it so that the present chimney could be used. DEPUTY MINISTER:

Re: Repairs at Pine Creek Indian Residential School.

Inspections have been made of the above noted school by Mr. Gow, of the Surveys and Engineering Branch, who reported on May 4, 1939, and by Mr. Parkinson, Architect of the Public Works Department, who submitted a report to the Surveys and Engineering Branch on August 2, 1938. Mr. Parkinson estimated that the repairs and alterations most urgently needed at the school would cost approximately $15,000.

Mr. Parkinson in his report, and after a discussion with the Church Authorities and with Mr. Desrosiers, who has undertaken repairs at a number of schools operated by the Catholic Church, recommended the replacement of 10 wrought iron columns and the jacking up and levelling of the floors by installing new columns. This work was proceeded with last year and has proved very satisfactory.

From the standpoint of fire hazard, the most urgent repairs and alterations necessary at this date appear to be the construction of a boiler house. At the present time the boiler room is in the basement of the school. Mr. Parkinson recommends the fireproofing of the boiler and fuel room at a cost of $550 and recommends the construction of new fireproof stairs throughout the building at a cost of $4,500. The suggestion has now been made -
been made, however - and this suggestion appears satisfactory to the Architects - that a fireproof boiler room be constructed outside the school but close enough to it to permit the use of the present chimney. In this way it is claimed most of the fire hazard now existing would be removed. It is pointed out that in the construction of residential schools in recent years the boiler has been installed in an attached building and not in the main building.

There is in the estimates of this year the sum of $5,000 that might be used for this work. It is altogether likely however that the construction of a fully fireproof boiler room will cost more than this amount. However, the church authorities, in a letter dated September 16, 1940, have intimated that they are prepared to proceed with this work and supply the difference between the amount provided in the estimates and the actual cost of the building.

I would recommend, therefore, subject to the approval of the Minister, that authority be granted to the Church Authorities to proceed with the construction of this building, on the understanding that the work will be subject to inspection by an architect satisfactory to the Department and that the cost cannot under any circumstances exceed the sum of $5,000.

Director.

re Indian School, Camperville, Man.

Dear Sir:

In connection with the construction of a proposed new boiler room at the above school, Father La Montagne and Mr. Derosier called in the office today to discuss the proposition.

I am given to understand that $5,000.00 is allocated in the present year's estimates for this work, and that it is advisable to have the building completed without delay.

Following some discussion I have recommended a building 32 feet long by 20 feet wide with walls of 12 inch concrete, erected at right angles to end of existing building and the construction of new stack. The sum allotted should be adequate for this work, assuming much of the labour by local Indian labour, the mechanical work may be supervised by the Engineer, Mr. Patterson, a very capable man. The boiler floor is recommended to be at same level of present floor, and the height of room an existing height, with a fireproof ceiling and 5 ply felt and gravel roof. The height of building above grade will approximate 7 feet.

It is also recommended to remove and connect each boiler separately so that the heating of the school will be protected until final completion, which if the work is commenced immediately should not be later than November 30th.

The boilers will be set with new fire brick and the existing drain in boiler room transferred to new boiler room.

As the boilers are fired with cord wood, the recommended size of boiler room will provide ample space for a good quantity of wood, without the necessity of constructing a separate fuel room.

Owing to the hazardous condition of the present boiler room, the construction of a new boiler room is very strongly recommended, and should be easily completed for the sum of $5,000.00 Meantime I will make a rough sketch, a copy of which will be given to Father La Montagne and a copy forwarded to you.

Yours truly,

E. Parkinson
District Resident Architect, D.P.W.

MEMORANDUM

FROM
The Office of the Resident Architect
DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC WORKS
Winnipeg, December 20th, 1940.

Dear Sir:

Re - Pine Creek Indian School, Camperville, Man.
New Boiler Room.

The new boiler room at above school was inspected as to its general construction on December 17th, 1940, and subject to some minor items noted under, the work generally is acceptable, in consideration of the period during construction and the distance from railroad.

Enclosed are blue prints showing my sketch to the Contractor and a floor plan of the actual construction, some changes from the original sketch are advantageous, others not so good.

The position of door from old building is better, but the interior length of boiler room is reduced 3 inches, being 13 ft. 11 inches from face of boiler tubes to exterior wall, or one inch less than the length of boiler tubes, this will cause to be cut a chase in the concrete wall to a minimum of two inches in depth for the renewal of defective heating tubes to boiler marked "A", the other boiler marked "B" will create no difficulty as the tubes are opposite the exterior door opening.

The bricking of boiler "A" to East side is not good, the bricks are not fully bedded and smoke has issued at some of the joints, the Engineer, Mr. Patterson, has given a thin coat of cement plaster over a portion, which appears to seal the joints. In constructing the East wall of boiler "A", the lower part approximately 14 inches high is of concrete, and has cracked through heat expansion, a portion having moved out of position one inch, the crack continues through the brickwork. The building was constructed to that specification and, therefore, the Contractor may be excused for running the rain water from roof over a scupper, instead of hopper end down pipe as originally intended.

In general with the above exceptions, good value is received for an expenditure of $5,000.00, and the building is a distinct improvement from fire hazard as previously existed.

Whilst in the building, I examined the newly erected interior columns and levelling of floors, and consider the work well done, though the floors are not perfectly level, there is great improvement.

Two photographs of the exterior of boiler room were taken and when prints are received, they will be forwarded to you.

Generally the Fathers of the school and the Engineer in charge, are very well pleased with the construction.

I have much pleasure in submitting this report.

Yours truly,

E. Parkinson,
District Resident Architect.

Sir,

During a recent visit to the Pine Creek Indian Residential School the Reverend Principal asked me to draw the attention of the Department to the condition of the storage batteries at present in use at the school. Various reports and representations have been made in regard to condition of the batteries and also to the kitchen stove which is not large enough for cooking for the large number of children in residence.

The capacity of the batteries is now so low that it is necessary to run the engine from four to eight hours during the night, and this consumes considerable fuel.

I pointed out to the Principal that owing to a state of National emergency it might be difficult to find money to replace the batteries and purchase an addition to the cook stove. However, he asked me to bring the matter to the attention of the Department.

Rèv. et cher Père,

Le compte ci-joint fut envoyé avec les autres comptes montrant les dépenses faites pour construire notre nouvelle chambre à bouilloires. Ce compte me fut retourné parce qu'il manquait des reçus. Je me suis fait parvenir les dits reçus et je vous envoie le tout. J'espère que tout sera satisfaisant. Vous verrez que je charge deux voyages fait à Dauphin, le taux régulier est de 15.00 du voyage. Je crois que ce n'est pas trop exagéré de charger 12.00.

L'architecte, Mr. Parkinson est venu faire son inspection cette semaine, il doit envoyer son rapport immédiatement à Ottawa. Selon lui la nouvelle chambre aurait dû être construite un pied plus longue. Il n'a pas semblé complètement satisfait. Je ne sais pas si c'est sa manière de dire les choses qui m'ont fait croire cela, mais d'après son expression, je crois qu'il aurait désiré que le travail soit plus soigné. Il y a certain petit détail que Mr. Desrosiers n'avait pas tout à fait fini, comme v.E. couvrir les tuyaux avec de l'amiante, il était entendu que Mr. Patterson devait faire ces différentes petites choses. L'architecte m'a demandé pourquoi le contracteur n'avait pas complété son travail. Je lui ai répondu que l'argent était dépensé et que le Département ne voulant pas que nous dépasseions la somme assignée, nous avons préféré laisser partir le contracteur et terminé nous même ces petites choses de peu d'importance, plutôt que de faire dépenser plus que ce qui nous était alloué. Il est parti en me disant, que considérant le temps, les circonstances et les lieux en définitive le travail était satisfaisant.

J'espère que le remboursement ne se fera pas trop attendre, car les finances sont basses. J'attends ce remboursement pour pouvoir contribuer à votre œuvre de Presse, comme il est bien entendu. Soyez certain que je ferai tout en mon pouvoir pour vous faire parvenir ma contribution le plus tôt possible.

Fraternellement vôtre in Xto Jesu & M.I.

C. Ruest, O.M.I.

December 30, 1941.

Sir,

During my recent inspection of the Pine Creek Indian Residential School, the Reverend Principal again asked me to take up with the Department the question of a new cook stove for the school. This matter has been brought to the attention of the Department in several reports. The store lids are now beginning to fall into the fire and the ovens are about done, being burnt out.

All fire equipment is in good shape with the exception of the hand equipment. I suggested that the contents of the hand pumps should be renewed. This has now been done, the Principal writing direct to the Department for authority.

The Principal advised me that at a recent inspection of boilers by the Provincial boiler Inspector it was suggested that a circular reservoir be made to hold rain water as the water at present in use was corroding the heating system. This was supposed to be embodied in the Inspectors' report to the Department. The circular reservoir to be made of cement capable of holding 20,000 gallons. The Principal would be willing to dig the excavation and to furnish the sand and gravel, if the Department would furnish the cement, forms and the labour of building. This would be an expensive undertaking at the present time, and this was pointed out to the Principal. However, he asked me to bring this matter to the attention of the Department as he felt that the boiler inspector had already taken the matter up.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

If possible you should quote a catalogue number. I am not certain that we will have funds for the purchase of this stove but if we have all the information necessary for the Purchasing Branch we will then be in a position to obtain prices and decide if the stove can be purchased now.

I have reviewed our files and can find no recent report from the Provincial Boiler Inspector. Is it only proposed to use the rain water in the heating system? If so, it is considered that the reservoir suggested by the Principal would be very much too large. Presumably the Principal has a copy of the Provincial Boiler Inspector's report and I would like to have an opportunity of reviewing this before making any decision regarding the supplying of material to build a reservoir.

Dear Sir,

Re. Pine Creek Indian Residential School, at Camperville.

In regards to a soft water cistern at the school, I would greatly suggest that a soft water reservoir should be built to prolong the life of those boilers. And I would recommend a reservoir large enough to supply all the boilers and the washing in the laundry also, so I would propose that a 1200 or at least a 1000 barrel reservoir be built.

I made a call on this heating system and the high pressure boiler on June 4th, and found that the tubes in one of the heating boilers were eaten out due to hard water conditions in that locality which have been giving trouble for some time. The piping and other equipment is greatly affected by the hard water.

Memorandum

Mr. C.W. Jackson

Indian Affairs Branch have submitted a requisition for two water softeners which Crane Limited, Winnipeg, Man., offer for immediate delivery at $493.91 net, f.o.b. Winnipeg, Man., tax included. This equipment is for the Pine Creek R.C. Indian Residential School, a Government-owned institution.

Mr. D.B. Gow, who at our request examined the water softeners, reports that they are new, and in good condition, and capable of softening a requisite amount of the alkaline lake water which has a hardness of 26 grains per U.S. Gallon.

The material needed to build a soft water cistern would cost $623.64 f.o.b. Winnipegosis. This alternative would ensure an adequate supply of soft water if there was sufficient rain. The first cost of the water softeners would be about $120 less, but there would be subsequent maintenance expenditures for salt and zeolite mineral. As the requisition calls for water softeners, it is assumed that the school authorities prefer these to the cistern.

The price quoted by Crane Limited on the softeners is fair and reasonable. We could not obtain them elsewhere without a priority as the steel used in the manufacture of the tanks is not rolled in Canadian mills. Likewise we have not been successful during the past year in obtaining requisite priority rating on water softeners for other western points.

I recommend that authority be granted to place the order for the two B.T. 33 Crane Maxlo water softeners with Crane Ltd., Winnipeg, Man., at their quoted price of $493.91 f.o.b. Winnipeg, tax included.

WMV/HC

Memorandum:

DEPARTMENTAL PURCHASING AGENT

I desire to refer to your memorandum of November 10, file 48,435-15-2 Man., with reference to a requisition submitted for the purchase of 2 water softeners for the Pine Creek Indian Residential School. The decision contained in your memorandum was conveyed to the Indian Agent who has taken up the matter with Inspector Hamilton. The latter writes as follows:

"The hot water has a severe chemical reaction on all metal and once it starts eating into the metal there appears no way to stop the process. Cold water does not have this effect. I saw a heavy 2" galvanized pipe leading to the washing machine with holes in it like a sprinkler and yet the water does not stand in this pipe; but the water passing through is very hot. In view of the severe shortage of steel and the difficulty in getting galvanized pipe, I think consideration should be given to the purchase of a water softener. I understand a suitable one is available in Winnipeg for about $500.00. I would point out further that the Reverend Father has used very little of the money allotted this year for repairs; and I would say further that this money was not needed due largely to the capable engineer who is interested in his work and is constantly on the job. In view of the saving in repairs which makes money available, I recommend that a water softener be installed. I am firmly convinced the investment will pay for itself over a period of years in saving on plumbing, steam fittings and tanks. I would be pleased to know the final decision concerning this matter."

I may add that when Mr. Phelan was in Winnipeg recently he met the Principal of the Pine Creek Residential School and the latter urged strongly that the water softeners...
be obtained. In view of the above, it would be appreciated if you could arrange to have the previous decision reconsidered.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Memorandum:

DEPARTMENTAL PURCHASING AGENT

I desire to refer to your memorandum of November 10, file 45,435-15-2 Man., with reference to a requisition submitted for the purchase of 2 water softeners for the Pine Creek Indian Residential School. The decision contained in your memorandum was conveyed to the Indian Agent who has taken up the matter with Inspector Hamilton. The latter writes as follows:

"The hot water has a severe chemical reaction on all metal and once it starts eating into the metal there appears no way to stop the process. Cold water does not have this effect. I saw a heavy 2" galvanized pipe leading to the washing machine with holes in it like a sprinkler and yet the water does not stand in this pipe; but the water passing through is very hot. In view of the severe shortage of steel and the difficulty in getting galvanized pipe, I think consideration should be given to the purchase of a water softener. I understand a suitable one is available in Winnipeg for about $500.00. I would point out further that the Reverend Father has used very little of the money allotted this year for repairs; and I would say further that this money was not needed due largely to the capable engineer who is interested in his work and is constantly on the job. In view of the saving in repairs which makes money available, I recommend that a water softener be installed. I am firmly convinced the investment will pay for itself over a period of years in saving on plumbing, steam fittings and tanks. I would be pleased to know the final decision concerning this matter."

I may add that when Mr. Phelan was in Winnipeg recently he met the Principal of the Pine Creek Residential School and the latter urged strongly that the water softeners...
be obtained. In view of the above, it would be appreciated if you could arrange to have the previous decision reconsidered.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Extract from Inspector Hamilton's report on the Pine Creek Indian Residential School visited on November 17, 1943.

The dormitories were clean, well aired and the beds neatly made. The fire alarm bell is in the girls' dormitory and can only be faintly heard in the boys' dormitory. Another bell should be installed on the boys' side. This installation is essential and if the bell is provided can no doubt be connected up by the engineer.

Paint is badly needed for exterior painting on the school, ice-house and machine-shed. If the paint is provided the Reverend Principal will arrange for the painting at his own expense.

I understand some money has been allowed this year but this is being used to put metal stripping on the windows and do general repair work.

A garage is needed and if funds can be made available next year the building should be allowed. The Reverend Principal wishes to build the garage adjoining the furnace room so that it can be easily heated. If the garage were built of cement it would be fireproof and I can see no objection to it being built adjacent to the furnace room.

I wish to report that during a recent visit to the Pine Creek Indian Residential School, the following necessary repairs were brought to attention and noted.

1) The high pressure boiler that runs the steam laundry boiler. The firebox will have to be relined with new fire brick and new arches are required. The outside brickwork will have to be checked by a competent bricklayer and it is possible that all new outside brickwork will be required. One new grate is required for this furnace, which is a "Pascal" Fort Arthur Shipbuilding Co. Limited.

2) The two heating boilers. These are made by the Vulcan Iron Works, Limited. All inside brick will have to be replaced and most probably all outside brickwork will have to be rebuilt. There is a spring under one corner and this has caused a sinking of the floor. The boiler inspector of the district has commented in regard to the condition of the three boilers. He claims they are not in first class condition according to test but certain brickwork and pipes etc will have to be attended to before another season. He further stated that the boilers at present are resting on the brickwork of the arches and by lugs in the outside brickwork. And that this construction was wrong and he will insist that the three boilers be hung from properly constructed iron standards. This would mean the renewal of all brickwork around the three boilers. He will be visiting the school in the near future and will be accompanied by Mr. Lock, Bricklayer of Dauphin and a complete report on the condition of the brickwork etc. will be furnished. A rough estimation of the brick required would be 2500 to 2700 field brick and 1000 common brick. A further report will be sent to the Department as soon as received.

3) The main drive shaft will have to be reset and babitted. It is also necessary to have the shaft relined. If the shaft is too badly out then a new shaft will be necessary together with eight (8) new sets of hanger bearings. The approximate cost of the new shaft (two pieces - 19' and 24' X 1 end 13/16 inches) would be $33.00, and the approximate cost of the bearings for the hangers - $30.00. A further report will be furnished when the shaft is taken down and its condition noted.

4) The Gurney Jacket Heater, No. 104-4253 requires all new grates. These grates are in sections and 7 sections are required. The total length of the heater is 65". These grates should be purchased as soon as possible as the heater is in constant use.

5) At the present time the laundry steam engine is being used for pumping water and driving the electric light.
generator, pending the return of the Lister engine at present in Winnipeg under repair. This engine has now a decided "knock" in the main bearing and the slide rods are cut and pitted. The engine will require an overhaul as soon as the Lister engine is returned. The work is a machine shop job and it is intended to truck the engine to Dauphin and have the work completed there.

6) By Dept. letter 126-1-5 dated Ottawa, January 5, 1945, $100.00 was authorized for the installation of a countershaft to run the generator. This is expected to be a permanent construction and to date the following is the outlay. Pulley and clutch $83.26 pulley and shaft $21.16. It is estimated that another $100.00 will be required to complete this work. Two (2) hangers will cost approximately $34.00 and the machining of key ways in shaft and the adjustment of bearings etc., the balance.

7) Attention was also drawn to the condition of the batteries. There are 56; these were purchased March 12, 1941, Order No. 6224, File 37,440-15-16, at a cost of $563.75. The guarantee is for 7 years. The Reverend Principal claims they will not now hold the charge and should be renewed before the 1st. of September. Some of the plates are slightly warped, but the jars are free of any undue amount of sediment. I would be pleased if this matter is taken up with the vendor of the batteries.

Further reports on the boilers etc., will be forwarded as received.

A G HAMILTON
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

Re: Water Line - Pine Creek School,
Dept. File 126-1-6 dated Feb.14/45.

I was at this school on February 22nd and 23rd and checked carefully into the need for renewing the hot water line and repairing the pressure boiler.

This pipe line has given constant trouble all winter. The pipes look fairly good but day after day leaks appear. In attempting to put in new pipe it is often found necessary to renew several feet because the pipe is soft. Undoubtedly the pipes are heavily corroded and pitted, and with the condition existing the action of the water softener which was installed around a year ago, has loosened the scale. The result is a thinner pipe badly clogged with loosened scale, lime and rust. This cannot be blown out because the pipe line makes many right angle turns where this foreign matter lodges. I discussed the subject first with Mr. F.W.Bumstead, Plumber, Dauphin, and also with Mr. Bell, the Provincial Fire Inspector. Both men are familiar with the situation; and both are convinced that a new line is required.

The Department have quotations from different firms, as well as from Mr. Bumstead. I understand Mr. Bumstead has been in business in Dauphin many years and that he does good work and is considered reliable.

I doubt if any firm would give a price on the work but from information gathered I am convinced it will cost from six to eight hundred dollars. Mr. Bumstead expressed the opinion that it would take two men from four to six weeks to complete a satisfactory job. The list of material appears large; but I understand it was carefully prepared after advice from both Mr. Bell and Mr. Bumstead. I would therefore recommend that the material be purchased. I would also recommend that the authority to proceed with the work be authorized as soon as possible so that the plumber engaged will be prepared to proceed with the work at a time most suitable to the Principal of the School.

The high pressure steam boiler needs relining with fire brick, new arches and one grate. The brick work around the boiler is badly cracked. I would suggest that the Provincial Inspector, Mr. Bell, be requested to give his recommendation regarding the brick work. If this is past repairing and requires re-building, I am sure the Inspector will request that the boiler be hung from a metal frame and then bricked in. This allows for expansion and slight adjustment without breaking the boiler water. In any event, the fire box must be relined with fire brick, the arches rebuilt and grate installed. If the brick work needs rebuilding the same bricks can be cleaned and used again. No doubt a small quantity of...
new brick will be required to replace those badly broken.

A.G. Hamilton,
Inspector of Indian Agencies
for Manitoba.

Dear Sir:

Would you kindly ask the Department to authorize the purchasing of a small Tractor Unit for our school farm. We have now a herd of 85 heads of cattle of which 12 milking cows and 8 horses. We are actually buying all the feed for our stock even hay.

Although the sell condition is poor, I am of the opinion that a good proportion of the feed and hay could be produced on our property providing we have the equipment to do the work on time.

The season is very short in this part of the country. Doing farm work with horses and old style equipment is a very slow process. By the time the ground is prepared and the seed put in, the season is far advanced; consequently our chances for a decent crop are very slight. With a small Tractor work could done more rapidly with better chances of producing good hay and part of the feed required for our stock.

For this reason I am kindly asking you to send my request to the Department.

Mr. J. Allard has on hand a Ford Tractor, cost Price $ 865.00 F.O.B. Dauphin.

Any one of these unit would take care of the work to be done on our farm.

Please kindly give this matter your usual consideration.

Very truly yours,

Dear Sir:

Re Indian School, Camperville, Man.

Our Inspector, Mr. J. H. Bell, reports that he has made an inspection of the boilers in the Indian School at Camperville.

He states that the ground condition under the cement floor of the boiler room is very poor as there is a certain amount of water seepage underneath the floor at all times and the boilers and setting have a tendency to settle down at one side or the other, due to the weight, causing the brick work to crack and fall in or out. I would, therefore, recommend that you make arrangements to have these boilers rebuilt, and, when rebuilding, that you put in proper concrete footings for supporting the brick work.

The high pressure boiler in the laundry room also requires to be rebricked as the firebox walls are in poor condition. Inspector Bell states that the foundation of this boiler is in fairly good shape above the ground level, therefore it would not need to have a new foundation placed under it.

I trust you will make arrangements to have this work carried out as soon as possible so that the boilers will be in good shape for next winter.

Yours very truly,

R. A. Stuart,
Deputy Minister.

Dear Sir:

Re Indian School, Camperville, Man.

Our Inspector, Mr. J. H. Bell, reports that he has made an inspection of the boilers in the Indian School at Camperville.

He states that the ground condition under the cement floor of the boiler room is very poor as there is a certain amount of water seepage underneath the floor at all times and the boilers and setting have a tendency to settle down at one side or the other, due to the weight, causing the brick work to crack and fall in or out. I would, therefore, recommend that you make arrangements to have these boilers rebuilt, and, when rebuilding, that you put in proper concrete footings for supporting the brick work.

The high pressure boiler in the laundry room also requires to be rebricked as the firebox walls are in poor condition. Inspector Bell states that the foundation of this boiler is in fairly good shape above the ground level, therefore it would not need to have a new foundation placed under it.

I trust you will make arrangements to have this work carried out as soon as possible so that the boilers will be in good shape for next winter.

Yours very truly,

With reference to the above noted letter, relative to repairs to the boilers, Pine Creek Residential School, I beg to attach hereto a letter received from the Reverend Principal on September 22nd last. I have held this letter pending corroboration by the Boiler Inspector. I have written to him on three occasions without reply. It is assumed he will not commit himself in this matter. To date the boilers appear to be holding up and probably will until fires are discontinued in the spring.

I wrote the Winnipeg Supply and Fuel Company on Sept. 20th, advising that I would inform them as soon as the foundation was laid and the work of bricking the boilers could be started. I believe they will be well pleased that this work cannot be done at this time, as they had more than enough work for the staff they had.

I beg to request that the sum of $150.00 be made again available by May 1st next year and that 50 sacks of cement be purchased for work on the foundations of the boilers, by that date. Accountable cheque from the Department, No. J1299 - $150.00, has been returned to Receiver General account, December 15, Sheet No.13.

The Reverend Principal states that the foundation will be ready for the brickwork by July 15th., and I would be pleased to be advised, before that date, if the Winnipeg Supply and Fuel Company's price for this work is again satisfactory.

J. Waite,
Indian agent.

September 22, 1945.

Mr. J. Waite, Indian Agent,
Portage la Prairie, Man.

Dear Sir:

Answering your letter of the 17th instant, I wish to inform you that Mr. J.H. Bell, upon his last visit September 14, 1945 has decided that work on the boilers will be done only next Spring. He is sending you his report giving reasons for postponement.

Essential repairs will be done by the school so that we may operate during the coming Winter. Work will be done according to plans early next Spring. I guarantee that everything will be ready for the Brick-layer on July 15, 1946.

Could you make arrangements so that a Brick-layer may be available and ready to start work on the above mentioned date.

About 50 bags of Cement will be needed to build up boilers' foundation according to plans. Would you give me authorization to purchase Cement from one of the Winnipegosis Lumberyard, or would the Department place the order? I wish the Cement will be here not later than May 1, 1946.

X X X

Very truly yours,

C. Ruest, O.M.I.
Ottawa, December 18, 1945.

Mr. J. Waite, Indian Agent,
Portage la Prairie, Man.

I have your letter of the 12th instant, in which you state that it has been decided to postpone the bricking of the boilers at the Pine Creek Indian Residential School until next July.

By that time it will have been nearly a year since we obtained the quotation from the Winnipeg Supply and Fuel Company, Limited. Conditions may be changed by next year and consequently I believe that about the middle of June you should ask the firm to give you another quotation on the work required and submit this for our consideration.

We will arrange to purchase the 50 sacks of cement and have it sent to the school before May 1, 1946. The sum of $150.00 will also be available, if required, and will be sent on receipt of a request from you.

I have your letter of the 22nd instant with reference to certain schools that use Oxygen and Acetylene.

Re: Community center for the Pine Creek Indian Residential School.

My dear Mr. Phelan:

You will recall my two previous letters re above matter. In order to overcome certain local difficulties, the Principal, Reverend Father Charles Ruest, O.M.I., has decided to build two community centers, one for the Pine Creek ex-pupils and one for the White and Half-Breed population of Camperville.

The center for the ex-pupils can be erected either on the school property or on the Indian Reserve and we will be guided in this matter by the advice of the Department. The school site offers certain advantages, such as heating as I am informed that if built close to the school, the heating plant of the school is large enough to take care of the heating problem.

It is proposed to build the walls with cement blocks, to the making of which Indians and older school pupils will be asked to donate their time. They have agreed to this already, so no trouble is anticipated in securing this free labour. There is an abundance of good sand and gravel which should render the making of these blocks an easy task.

Of course, a cement block machine will have to be bought. I am informed that there is in Quebec city a manufacture who makes these machines and sells them for $400.00. If the Department could contribute the purchase of this machine and a carload of cement, this project of a community center...
would be well launched.

Hoping to hear favourably from you I remain, dear Mr. Phelan,

Very truly yours,

J.O. Plourde, O.M.I.

Re: Concrete Block Machine for Pine Creek Indian School.

Attention: Mr. P. Phelan.

My dear Mr. Phelan:

This morning I visited the plant of Mr. Hayley, Hurdsman's Road, Ottawa, for the purpose of securing information on the proper kind of machine to purchase for the above school. I saw Mr. Hayley personally and received valuable information from him. He advises the purchase of a Model C Clipper Stripper as well as a 9 cubic foot concrete mixer and cast iron pallets to handle the blocks. This machine can be operated with a five horse power gasoline engine which the school can supply. It will easily make from 6 to 800 blocks per day.

The London Concrete Machinery Co. of London, Canada, will gladly supply additional information about this machine and its various features.

I am enclosing along with this letter, the latest catalogue of the London Concrete Machinery Co., with a note at the bottom of the illustration showing the machine which I was advised to buy.

As the building season is very short in Pine Creek, I hope that you will be able to purchase this equipment in the very near future.

Yours very truly,

J.O. Plourde, O.M.I.

During a recent visit to the Pine Creek Indian Residential School, the Provincial Boiler Inspector was contacted with regard to the three boilers that are being repaired at the School. He made a complete inspection and I attach hereto his reports.

You will kindly note that one of the heating boilers is condemned and a new one will have to be purchased. The particulars regarding this boiler are shown on the report. The Rev. Principal makes request that a new boiler be furnished with a steel fire box which will eliminate rebricking from time to time. It is further recommended and necessary that new tubes be installed in the other heating boiler and that two extra flues be furnished for repair purposes.

The Inspector also recommends that the high pressure boiler be reset farther away from the wall and that the walls be covered with fire resistant material. Regarding this boiler, I wish to refer to my report of the 26th of February 1945, in which a new set of grates was requested for this boiler. These grates are still required.
I also wish to refer to the above-mentioned report in connection with paragraph four relative to the jacket heater. A new jacket heater of the upright variety is very necessary. The tank for this heater is 12' by 3' tubular with a capacity of 3000 gallons. The water in the boiler room which has been responsible for the sinking of the boilers is evidently heavy seepage and it is recommended that a sump hole be dug and an automatic sump pump installed. This installation will require a two horse-power engine.

The heating of the School has not been satisfactory and the Rev. Principal has suggested that a vacuum system be installed.

The brick work of the boilers has been torn down and the heating boilers have been removed to the outside. The new excavation is approximately two feet deep and at the time of my visit this excavation was full of water. This will have to be filled with stone and cement to a height of four inches above the boiler room floor. All this material will have to be hauled. The reinstallation of the high pressure boiler will necessitate the tearing down of the old boiler cement foundation, possibly cutting the cement floor to put in new footings, and a request is made for a further advance of $500.00 in an accountable cheque so this work may be proceeded with immediately. The Rev. Father states that his staff is not experienced enough to refit the boiler connections after the installation of the three boilers is made and requests that the services of Mr. Bumstead, Steam-fitter of Dauphin, be engaged to do this work.
I wish to refer to paragraph seven of my report of February 26th 1945 calling attention to the batteries, a new set should be installed before winter sets in.

In connection with Mr. Hoey's memorandum of June 29th, 1946, and your notation of July 3rd, 1946 thereon, you are advised as follows:

An analysis of points raised by the Indian Agent and the Boiler Inspector indicates that:

2. Heating Boiler (No. 2) is condemned and is not recommended for further service.

3. Heating Boiler (No. 3) needs all new tubes and a new brick setting along with a new set of grates.

4. The jacket heater is worn out and is no longer serviceable.

5. A seepage of water in the boiler room has caused the floor to settle and work is now being carried out to replace the floor. The heating boilers have been moved outside the building to facilitate new floor construction.

6. A new sump pit with sump pump to keep boiler room drained, appears necessary.

7. New batteries were requested in Mr. Waite's report of February 26th, 1945, but no action to date has been taken.

8. The Heating system does not function satisfactorily.

Memorandum

Re: Pine Creek Indian Residential School,
Camperville - Manitoba.

In connection with your memorandum of July 26th, 1946 in which you approved of an inspection of the above by our Mr. Hergreaves, you are advised as follows:

A complete inspection of the Plumbing, Heating, Domestic Hot Water and Laundry Services was carried out on August 7th, 8th and 9th, 1946 and the following report outlines the conditions.

In the first place, the 2 low pressure heating boilers had been disconnected, dismantled and moved to the yard and a new concrete floor slab laid in the boiler room. This new work seems to be satisfactory and the seepage seems to have been localized into one corner of the building, where a pit has been left. Some type of sump pump will be required to dispose of the water which will be dealt with later in this report.

The high pressure boiler also has been dismantled and disconnected and is stored in the laundry, pending alterations to the space wherein it is to be set up. The brick settings for all 3 boilers have of course, also been torn down and this material is of very little, if any, further use. It is pointed out at this stage that the low pressure boilers are located in the extreme north end of the original school buildings, while the high pressure boiler is located in an added wing in the east side of the building or Service Wing. No fault is to be found with either of these locations.

The Provincial Boiler Inspector in his reports dated June 5th and June 14th has approved of a 100 lb. operating pressure for the high pressure boiler. This appears to be in order. He has condemned one low pressure heating boiler and called for a complete re-fit of the other one before it can be used again. Actually, both low pressure boilers are in such poor condition that they should be thrown away if repairs were attempted and it is strongly recommended that this Service accept no responsibility if repairs are ordered.

As regards heating, the school is in a state of dire emergency and a telegram was dispatched to the Chief Engineer of Engineering and Construction Service, asking for authority to institute immediate action to cover temporarily, the heating requirements. Authority having been granted, up to the sum of $1000.00 a steamfitter, Mr. Frank Rumstead, of Dauphin, Manitoba, was called in and asked to begin work immediately, as outlined below.

J. M. Wardle, Esq.,
Director,
Surveys and Engineering Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
OTTAWA.

Continuing with the report, it was found, as mentioned above, that the radiators are all too small. Evidently the job was originally calculated for too small a temperature range and the design was not consistent with good practice. This building should have been figured from 30° below zero outside to 70° inside.

As it is a one pipe system, most of the radiators can have sections added if matching patterns are obtainable. Otherwise, new additional radiators can be connected. The main appears to be satisfactory for the most part but some adjustment is necessary.

The Domestic Hot Water system needs a new jacket heater. The present unit is worn-out and ready for collapse. A new unit is strongly recommended.

The plumbing is in very bad condition throughout. Lead waste pipe, installed many years ago, is in very bad shape, being taped and repaired in many places. No traps are provided on individual basins in the dormitories and the venting is poorly arranged.

Only ingenious maintenance, brought about under almost hopeless conditions, has kept the system in operation and it is evident that a major breakdown is not far distant.

The ceiling over the top floor should be insulated. The roof should be re-shingled. Many leaks were noted.

Summarizing, it is recommended that the following work be done:

As pointed out before, the heating boiler must be purchased and installed at the very earliest moment and too much stress cannot be placed on the serious results that will certainly occur if this boiler is not provided.

The following work should be undertaken at an early date:
(a) Provide enough new radiators or sections to properly heat the building.
(b) Make necessary adjustments to the piping. This can be kept to a reasonable minimum.
(c) All plumbing fixtures to be provided with individual traps where such are missing and new wrought iron waste pipe and new wrought iron or cast iron vent pipe installed.
(d) A new shingle roof is required and where sheathing and tar paper has deteriorated, replacements to be provided.
(e) Windows to be checked and made tight. It is felt that this item can be handled by the school staff.
(f) One new jacket heater required.
(g) A list of small items which the school staff could undertake to be made out for their guidance.

It is estimated that in addition to the authorized cost of the emergency heating hook-up amounting to approximately $1000.00, the cost of installing a new low pressure heating boiler with attendant installation cost and repairs to the building, including additional redistillation, piping and plumbing revisions, will cost in the neighbourhood of $8500.00.

T.S. Miller
Chief Engineer.
Ottawa, August 23rd, 1946.

Mr. Hoey

Re: Pine Creek Indian Residential School,
Camperville, Manitoba.

With further reference to Mr. Mills' memorandum of July 23rd last, I am enclosing, for your information, another memorandum from him, dated August 19th, which embodies a report by Mr. Hargreaves and which is self-explanatory.

It should be noted in particular that once cold weather sets in the high pressure boiler alone when reconnected will not be able to heat the school sufficiently to permit its occupation by pupils even though no steam is used for laundry purposes. The high pressure boiler can supply only 65% of the proper load for the present inadequate radiation. This existing radiation is only about 50% of the surface needed to heat the school properly.

It will also be noted that the additional repairs and renewals are estimated to cost $8,500 and that immediate steps should be taken to purchase a new heating boiler of the type referred to in the last paragraph of page 2 of Mr. Mills' memorandum of August 19th.

Kindly advise of your wishes in this matter and the amount of funds that will be available for the project.

Director.

Memorandum:

DIRECTOR, SURVEYS and ENGINEERING BRANCH

Re: Pine Creek Indian Residential School,
Camperville, Manitoba.

I have your memorandum of August 23, with reference to the above, and note that you estimate the cost of installing a new low pressure heating boiler, with attendant installation cost and also the repairs to the building, including additional radiation, piping, etc., at approximately $8,500.00.

Subsequent to the receipt of your memorandum, Mr. Buck phoned the Superintendent of Welfare and Training, and during the course of the conversation we ascertained that to supply the new heating boiler that is required and to install same would involve a cost of about $4,000.00. Mr. Buck was informed that we could find this amount but that the other repairs required would have to wait until next year.

Mr. Buck then stated that your Branch had made enquiries with regard to a new heating boiler and that you had been informed it would be approximately seven months before this could be secured.

As you know, our residential schools are due to open early in September, and if a new boiler cannot be obtained it would involve closing this school for practically the whole of 1946-47.

Subsequently we phoned Reverend M. Lavigne, O.M.I., Provincial of the Oblate Order, under whose jurisdiction this...
school is operated, and informed him of the condition that had arisen. We asked him if he knew of any place where a boiler could be secured.

On the afternoon of August 29 Father Lavigne phoned from St. Boniface to say that he had been in touch with the Port Arthur Shipbuilding and Boiler Company, Port Arthur, Ontario, and that they had informed him they could build the boiler required within four weeks.

I would therefore appreciate it if you would let me have immediate specifications for the boiler that is needed, in order that we may have the Departmental Purchasing Agent endeavour to secure it.

Director.

1. SCOPE OF WORK:
This specification and the accompanying plan are intended to provide for the installation and connecting up of a new low pressure steam heating boiler at the above. The Contractor shall take all measurements at the building, set out all work and be responsible for the quality of same. Except for the boiler, which will be delivered to the job by others, he shall provide all labor, transportation, material and plant and shall give his personal and constant attention to the work and be responsible for any damage done to other work, incidental to the execution of his own.

2. VISIT THE SITE:
The Contractor shall visit the site and thoroughly acquaint himself with the conditions under which the work will be done and govern himself accordingly.

3. MATERIALS AND WORKMANSHIP:
All materials shall be new, except as hereinafter noted, and the best of their respective kinds, sound and free from defects.

Workmanship shall be of the best and all work shall be done in a neat manner, with due attention given to the grading of pipes and making connections. All connections shall be made so as to permit free and unobstructed flow at all times and adequate provision shall be made for expansion.

4. VALVES:
All valves shall be gate valves, 2" and under, all brass; over 2" iron body, bronze fitted, or an approved type.

The Contractor shall examine the existing valves which were formerly in use in the boiler room, and if any valves of the proper sizes are found fit for service, he may, at his discretion, and with the approval of the Principal, use same after having thoroughly cleaned and repacked valves where necessary. If any old valves are used, they must be refitted so that they will be equal to the demands of service.
5. Drip Traps:

The low pressure header in boiler room shall be dripped through a 3/4" float and thermostatic trap, complete with valves, strainer, unions, scale pocket, etc., to ensure complete and rapid elimination of the condensation.

6. Piping:

All steam and return piping shall be standard weight black steel pipe put together with cast iron screwed fittings, or flanged where required. All pipe shall be carefully reamed before assembly and pipe compound shall be applied to pipe threads only.

Piping shall be run substantially as shown on plans, with swing joints to compensate for expansion where indicated or required and tested to 100 p.s.i. before covering is applied.

Alternatively, pipe may be welded, using approved welding fittings, and conforming with the best pipe welding practice, but if welding is contemplated, this must be so stated by the Contractor. Sufficient flanged connections or unions shall be left for convenient assembly and dismantling for repair and cleaning. Welding shall be done only by recognised skilled pipe line welders, and satisfactory evidence of the skill and experience of each welder employed shall be submitted to the Chief Engineer, Engineering Construction Service, Department of Mines and Energy, his accredited representative, for approval before work is commenced.

7. Hangers:

The low pressure header shall be supported by means of adjustable ring type hangers on 3/8" pipe, spaced to ceiling and spaced equi-distant on not more than 24" centres.

Any brackets used shall be spaced not more than 8'-0" apart on the smaller lines.

8. Covering:

All steam mains shall be covered with asbestos air cell sectional pipe covering, carried down and fitted around hangers, where such occur, and fitted around elbows, tees, valves, etc., and be covered with long fibre asbestos cement and cotton, as specified for pipes. Flanges and unions shall not be covered, nor return mains, unless so noted.

Boiler shall be covered 1" thick with 4" mesh firebrick blocks wired in place, and plastered 1" deep with long fibre asbestos cement, applied in 2 coats, the second coat to be tempered with 10% Portland cement and allowed to dry to a smooth finish. Paint 2 coats with heat resisting waterproof paint of an approved colour. Colour to be approved by the Reverend Principal.

Dear Sir:

I wish to report that our New Boiler has been temporary installed on the Church heating system for Xmas. The complete installation has been impossible, lack of material. We are still heating the school with our high pressure boiler. Mr. Bunstead expect to complete work immediately after New Year's Day.

The New boiler has been operating two days and two nights, it is working perfectly.

As you know the return water is pumped back in the boiler by an automatic condensation pump operated by a one H.P. electric motor.

As I have already pointed out and as you have already reported to the Department our actual set of batteries are very well done. So well done that it would be unsafe to depend on same to operate the motor of the new boiler. This motor failing would cause the ruin of the boiler. While heating with the new boiler we have kept the Diesel engine running so that there would be enough juice in the batteries to take care of them after operating the pump. You know that it is impossible to run this Diesel engine day and night for the rest of the Winter.

May I also point out that we have had trouble on Xmas day with our high pressure boiler; a flue has been leaking. For a while we were in serious trouble, but we manage to repair the flue without further damage.

No heat during four long hours and a terrible cold wind outside. The school was near freezing point when we were ready to start fire again.

This shows that we are really in need of the new boiler at most and in absolute need of a new set of batteries to operate same. It is urgent.

On August 22, 1946 Mr. Jack Cooper, Inspector of the Globelite Co., has inspected our batteries. The following is his recommendation: "When batteries replaced they shall be Type W 21 or G 19 for 40 amp discharge. This shows that the actual batteries are way too small for the work to be done, specially with one more motor to increase the load.

When a new set is installed ask the Company who will supply same to send a man to see that the Installation, connection, etc. are done properly.

Kindly give your immediate attention to this serious matter, it is urgent, may I once again insist on the recommendation done by Mr. Cooper for a larger set of batteries.

Very truly yours,

C. Ruest, O.M.I.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

Re: Pine Cree Indian Residential School,
Gamberville - Manitoba.

We are in receipt of your memorandum dated May 29th, to which is attached Mr. Rose's inspection report, along with the Contractor's guarantee covering materials and workmanship.

When our Mr. Hargreaves visited the school, the heating boilers had been removed and the high pressure boiler had been dismantled, as you will no doubt recall. Since the heating boilers were deemed unfit for further service, and owing to the lateness of the season, it was considered advisable to authorize the immediate setting up of the high pressure boiler, and to make temporary connections to the heating mains until such time as a new heating boiler could be procured and installed.

Acting on this authority, Mr. Bustead was instructed to carry out the work and to employ competent brick setters to enclose the high pressure boiler. Mr. Hargreaves met the brick setters and having previously investigated their record, which included over 100 such installations, thoroughly discussed the installation with them, leaving a sketch covering the essential requirements. Mr. Bustead was given to understand that he was to be the general contractor and the only organization with which the Department would deal. A drawing was supplied, on which the necessary specifications were noted.

The school operating staff was repeatedly advised not to start off with a roaring fire, but rather, to carry small fires for several days until the brickwork was thoroughly dried out, which is always the procedure to be followed in such installations.

Mr. Rose intimates in the last paragraph of his report, that the instructions issued at that time were evidently disregarded, and that too heavy a fire was started initially, which in our opinion would certainly cause such cracks to appear. Under the circumstances, and in view of the very good reputation of the contractors concerned, we are not inclined to hold them responsible for the cracks.

However, before the work is accepted for final payment, the cracks to which Mr. Rose has drawn attention, should be well packed, using asbestos rope and plastic asbestos cement as required, and we would request that you issue the necessary instructions to Mr. Bustead, and assign one of your engineers as soon as possible to make a final inspection before a fire is started.

He should be authorized to instruct the school authorities to start a slow drying out fire and maintain this for several days, pointing out to them that they are not free of this responsibility.

Re: 126-1-5 (W.T.L.) September 18, 1947.

In reply to the above noted letter, I beg to advise that the Reverend Principal of the Pine Creek School was consulted this date in connection with the proposed barn for the school. With him was a lumber merchant from Duck Bay, which is in the vicinity of the school. The proposal that the barn be constructed with a loft instead of a feed shed did not meet with favour. The material for the barn, proposed by the Principal, is all 2 X 4 dimension. The feed shed is the same. To put on a loft, heavier material would be required, and the cost would be approximately the same. The feed shed, as proposed, is possibly more suitable for the district, as no moisture from the barn can penetrate and spoil feed. It would be possible to use local lumber, and a saving of between $500.00 and $600.00 effected. The lumber dealer, accompanying the Principal, stated that rough lumber was selling at $50.00 per M., and would cost $2.00 per M., delivered at the site. For the siding and inside shiplap, the rough lumber would have to be taken to a planer, situated at Winnipegosis. The cost of making siding and shiplap would be $8.00 per M., plus $4.00 per M. freighting. This would mean that the siding and shiplap could be delivered at the building site for $62.00 per M. Rough lumber could be used for the dimension and sheeting. This would mean that only shingles, nails, windows, paper, hardware and doors would have to be shipped in. The lumberman suggested that the order be placed as soon as possible so that the 6 X 6 needed in the construction could be cut this winter. The Principal figured
on using three 2 X 6, laminated, for beams. The cutting of 6 X 6 would be a saving in labour and material.

The suggested barn is only of a size to accommodate the following stock. Six horses, sixteen cows, a calf pen and a bull pen.

The prices quoted to the Department for material were from a lumber yard in Winnipeg.

If it is intended to build the barn next summer, the gravel for the foundation should be hauled before freeze-up this fall. If allowed this fall, I beg to request that I be advised immediately, just now trucks are not busy. In a month's time all available trucks will be on the fish haul. If not hauled this fall no building can be done next summer, as it will be June before the gravel pit will thaw enough to allow digging.

J. Waite,
Indian Agent.
