Report on Pine Creek Residential School.

A one horse power motor is being used for pumping the return to the heating boiler. This motor makes a terrible drag on the batteries and a one quarter horse power motor would do the job satisfactorily. I would suggest that the one horse power motor and pump be kept, in case the smaller motor should break down. The breaking down of this unit would mean that the school would have to be closed until such time as the motor or pump could be repaired. This would mean a trip to Dauphin, approximately 100 miles. The unit required would be a 60 cycle motor, D.C. power 110, also one centrifical pump 7 lbs. pressure. The approximate cost of this unit $75.00.

The Reverend Principal claims the Lister engine, 10 H.P., is not powerful enough to charge the batteries and feels that a 20 H.P. engine should be provided. The batteries are sulphating to some extent and I beg to suggest that an electrical engineer from Munro-Edwards Ltd., Wall St., Winnipeg be instructed to visit the school and check the system. It is my opinion that there is a leak in the system and the present charge is not getting through to the batteries. The switch board was installed and built by the firm mentioned above.

A new wood-shed has been built immediately adjoining the pressure boiler. In its present state it is dangerous. It is within a few feet of the boiler, and the wood wall has been exposed. I requested the Principal to purchase 7 pcs. of 4 X 10 and 5 pcs. of 4 X 8 galvanized No. 22 iron to cover the wall and the door jambs, which were also exposed. The account for the galvanized iron to be forwarded to the Department. I trust my action in this matter was in order. It would have immediately come to the attention of a fire inspector and some criticism result.

There were two washing machines at the school, both installed in 1929. One machine was in pieces and cannot be repaired. This means extra work and strain for the washer still in use. This machine is also about done. The Reverend Principal suggested that one large washing machine be installed in place of the two that are practically finished. A 42 X 54 manufactured by the Beaver Merit Washers, Beaver Laundry Machinery Co., Limited, Toronto. I might state that both the washers installed in 1929, were according to the Principal, second-hand at that time.

I wish to refer to agency report dated November 28, 1946, and Department reply thereto, 126-105 (W.T.I.) of December 4th. My report refers especially to the condition of the roof and the wash bowls in both dormitories. Nothing has been done in either case. I would now suggest that some improvement be made to the dormitories. The whole roof down to the plate will have to be torn off and a new roof put on. At very little extra cost, a great improvement could be made to the dormitories, which are dark and depressing. I would suggest that the third storey, which consists of sheeting and shingles, lath and plastered inside, be entirely removed and re-built of brick or similar material. More and larger windows should be installed. The present windows are of the casement variety, giving very little light except in the immediate vicinity. All the frames and casements will have to be renewed in the very near future as

Dear Sir:

Re: File 30-39 New Barn at Pine Creek School.

Answering your letter of the 17th instant, I wish to inform that the actual barn building measures, 130 ft. long, 52 ft. wide and 16 ft. studding. Out of this 62' x 52' x 16' is the barn properly the rest is a feed shed, with an underground shelter for cattle.

You know the condition of the actual building, it is simply falling into pieces. Some 27 years ago it has been question of building a new one, since then mostly every fall considerable repair and patching has been done to the old building. It is terribly cold, water freezing even when full of cattle. The studdings are rotten at both ends, so are the joists. Above the barn there is a hay loft which collects all the moisture and dampness of the barn. The ceiling and floor are rotten so badly that we have to walk on the joists to prevent falling through. It is simply and completely done for.

There are only two alternatives, either build a new barn next summer or sell the stock next fall. Selling the stock in such a cold and damp barn is far from being a paying proposition, unfortunately I was forced to do it for the past 9 years.

Please kindly find from the Department what they wish me to do; either build a new barn next summer or sell the stock in the coming fall.

Very truly yours,

C. Ruest, O.M.I.

MEMORANDUM

Re: Pine Creek Indian Residential School,
Camperville, Manitoba.

With reference to the memorandum from Mr. Hoey dated November 28th last and your marginal notation thereon dated 1/12/47 regarding improvements to the above school recommended by Indian Agent Waite, we have received a letter from Mr. D.B. Gow, Winnipeg, which reads in part as follows:

"This Indian School is situated about twenty miles from the railway and is inaccessible by car during the winter months. Mr. Waite has suggested rebuilding of the roof, amongst many other things. I do not believe that an inspection at this time, with the roof covered with ice and snow, would give us information upon what we would require in order to outline roof alterations.

Furthermore, in view of the isolated nature of the school, it would be impossible to carry out any repair work before the end of the present fiscal year or even to get any material to the site. We will arrange to discuss the situation with Mr. Waite and ascertain what arrangements, if any, can be made to visit the school at this time but we would strongly recommend that the inspection, for best results, should be postponed until spring."

You will note that Mr. Gow, for reasons stated strongly recommends that an inspection of the school should be postponed until the spring, and we concur in this recommendation.

If, however, after further discussion of the situation with Indian Agent Waite, Mr. Gow should offer any practical suggestion for carrying out necessary minor repairs during the present fiscal year, we will advise you accordingly.

Chief Engineer.

B.A. Gibson, Esq.,
Director,
Lands and Development Services Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

In a telephone call this morning from the Reverend Principal, Pine Creek Residential School, I was informed that the tubes in the high pressure boiler were now burnt out and should be immediately replaced.

March 5, 1948.

AIR MAIL

Mr. J. Waite, Indian Agent,
Portage la Prairie, Manitoba.

We have your letter of the 4th instant, file 39-39C (127) with reference to the Pine Creek Residential School.

The request for the tubes was forwarded to us on February 25th, 1947 and we wrote you on May 8th, 1947 attaching copy of the quotation received by our Purchasing Branch from the Vulcan Iron Works. However, the principal answered our letter by stating that the jacket heater would be supplied and apparently we inferred at that time that the tubes were not necessary and consequently they were not ordered.

The quotation that we received from the Vulcan Iron Works shown in a letter forwarded to you on May 8th was as follows:

28 only tubes, 3" diameter outside measure, 10 ft. long $135.
1 only boiler tube expander for 3" tubes $40.
1 only beading tool, 6" long $9.
1 only tube cleaner type of combination $11.

TOTAL...........$195.

I suggest that you communicate with Vulcan Iron Works, Sutherland Avenue, Winnipeg and ascertain if they can supply the tubes at the same price as quoted last year. If not, you should obtain their price and submit same to us by air mail and we will arrange to have a purchase order issued.
With reference to your second letter of March 4th, the Department does not supply cups, saucers, plates, etc., to Indian residential schools. If these articles can be obtained from the War Assets Corporation, the school should communicate with the Branch of War Assets Corporation from whom the quotation was secured and make the purchase direct. Payment of same should be made from school funds.

Bernard F. Neary
Superintendent of Education.

Gentlemen:

Re: Additional power for the Indian School at Camperville.

Last week we had a visit from the Father in charge of this school, also one of the Brothers, at which time they brought in for repair a 10/2 Lister diesel engine which they have been using for the past several years on their lighting plant.

At the time of their visit they raised the point of insufficient power to enable them to properly charge their batteries and pump water at the same time. We carefully went into the matter of overcoming this problem in the most economical manner, and our proposal or recommendation to them to which they agreed, was that we supply an additional Type 10/2 Lister Diesel Engine, radiator cooled, which they could install with their present generator. Then we would overhaul their old engine which they brought in and return same to them, and this engine could be used to drive the water pump. This would split up the load, and would also give them two identical engines which could be used either for the pump or the generator in the event of failure of one of the units. This plan would also have the advantage in that all parts for the two engines would be identical; this would effect quite a saving.

Memorandum

Re Pine Creek Indian Residential School
Camperville, Manitoba

We are in receipt of a letter from Mr. Hoey under date of July 14th, 1948, to which was attached three memoranda covering inspections of the above, carried out by Mr. Wallace of Mr. Gov's staff.

The first memorandum deals with the conditions of the roof. This phase of the work is being studied by our Mr. Rankin and will be reported on at a later date.

The second memorandum, relating to the condition of the high pressure boiler and jacket heater, and the third memorandum referring to the bread mixer, have been analysed and the following report and recommendation is submitted for your information and transmission to the Indian Affairs Branch.

Following an inspection of the mechanical services at the above by our Mr. Hargreaves on August 6th to 8th inclusive, 1948, our recommendation dated August 19th, 1948, was forwarded to Mr. Wardle. This memorandum contained a general report with reference to the boiler and jacket heater and definite recommendations were made.

Acting on the recommendations in part, the high pressure boiler was set up on a concrete base which was prepared by the members of the school staff and bricked in to directions left with the bricklayers by our Heating Engineer. The school authorities were advised to keep a very low fire in the boiler for drying out purposes for at least a week and then to commence at the brickwork would fail if a heavy fire was started and maintained before a thorough drying out had taken place. Evidently this warning was not taken seriously and the brickwork cracked within a short time of its installation. The bricklayers were recalled to the job and made repairs which were considered satisfactory by the Indian Agent and the school authorities. Mr. Wallace reports that the brickwork is again badly cracked and that escaping smoke and flue gases are causing a great deal of trouble. He also reports that the tubes are leaking and suggests that they should be replaced. The Provincial Boiler Inspector in his report dated October 6th, 1947, states that the condition of this boiler is good but that a complete new set of tubes should be installed.

R.A. Gibson, Esq.,
Director,
Lands & Development Services Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.
If the brickwork in this boiler setting has not buckled, it is likely that satisfactory repairs can be made. Since no mention is made by Mr. Wallace to the effect that buckling has taken place, it is recommended that Mr. Wallace's suggestions for repairing the present setting be carried out. They are as follows:

(1) A high temperature cement with negligible shrinkage qualities equal to "Demon Air Set", as manufactured by the Plibrico Jointless Firebrick Company Limited of New Toronto, be applied to the interior of the brick setting in addition to an insulating cement made by the same people known as "Eagle Cement 66". A thick pliable mixture of the two cements should be thoroughly applied and forced into the cracks of the interior brickwork and the outside of the setting should be treated with a liberal coating of "Demon Air Set".

It is again pointed out that no matter how satisfactory a repair job is made, the same cracking of the walls will occur if a heavy fire is started and maintained before the new work has thoroughly dried out. It is felt that the school authorities should be forcibly reminded of their obligations in this regard.

(2) It is recommended that the Provincial Boiler Inspector's advice be followed with reference to a complete set of new tubes for this boiler. There are approximately 28 tubes ten feet long and at an estimated price of fifty cents per lineal foot with a likely $300.00 installation charge, the cost would amount to approximately $450.00.

(3) It is suggested that a new jacket heater be purchased and installed to replace the existing unit which was found to be practically burnt out at the time of the inspection made by our Heating Engineer in 1946. The new jacket heater should be equal to that made by the Gurney Manufacturing Company of Canada Limited, high test type No. 18-5 H.T. 2, having a tank capacity of 560 Imperial Gallons with an hourly capacity of approximately 100 gallons through 100 degrees temperature.

(4) Mr. Wallace's suggestion with regard to replacing the 5 H.P. gasoline engine located in the bakery, with a 1-1/2 H.P. electric motor, is concurred in and it is recommended that this be carried out.

Proposed Fire Escapes.

In your marginal note on Mr. Hoey's memorandum to you dated November 28, 1947, and further to our letter of the 6th instant, we have now received a report from Mr. Gow covering an inspection by Mr. Wallace of Mr. Gow's staff.

As Mr. Hoey indicates in his memorandum, the existing pole fire escapes are unsatisfactory. Mr. Wallace suggests two alternatives, namely, tubular steel fire escapes or wrought iron stairways.

We concur with his recommendation that the former are preferable. Being completely enclosed their efficiency is unaffected by weather, snow, ice, flame, smoke or falling objects. They provide faster and safer removal of personnel from the building. Two escape tubes 30 in diameter sloped at 30° would be placed on the rear wall of the school. October 25, 1939 - A memorandum from Indian Affairs Branch stated that certain repairs would be carried out by church authorities. We have no record of what repairs were carried out, if any.

Here the matter rested until November 28, 1947, when Indian Agent J. Waite reported that the roof was in such bad condition that he suggested it be removed and requested an inspection by an engineer of this Department.

June 2, 1948 - Mr. Hoey advised that the Principal reported that the school was in a serious predicament regarding the condition of the roof and requesting it be replaced at once.

July 12, 1948 - Brings us to the present report from Mr. Gow, which is very detailed and lengthy. In effect, it is recommended that the following repairs be undertaken.

The entire roof and ceiling be removed and rebuilt. Exterior frame walls (Mansard) of third storey to be re-covered with shiplap, plaster board and be insulated. The entire roof to be covered by asphalt shingles. Deteriorated plaster of interior partitions to be replaced by shiplap and plaster board. We concur in these recommendations. Mr. Gow's estimate for this work, which includes allowance for considerable salvage, is Seven Thousand and Ninety-Seven Dollars ($7,097.00).

We have made preliminary designs for a proposed new roof construction, which, together with additional work as described in the recommendations will, we estimate, cost in the vicinity of $11,970.00.

This estimate is considerably more than that of Mr. Gow's office. We propose an entirely new roof construction with little allowance made for salvage value of the forty (40) year old small sized lumber from the demolished roof. We also include adequately insulated walls and ceiling for the dormitories which have been inadequately heated and have proved a strain on the heating equipment.

In his report, Mr. W.H. Wallace of Mr. Gow's staff, states that additional columns have been placed under floor beams and although there is still a slope to the floors, Mr. Wallace states it is not considered to be of a serious nature. A new set of plans showing changes and additions since 1939 to date is being prepared by Mr. Gow's staff and will be forwarded here for our use.

Upon receipt of these plans from Mr. Gow, we shall check the floor construction and report whether or not these structural changes have been made and whether the floor system of the school is safe for occupancy.

Chief Engineer.

We recently received a report from the Lands and Development Services in connection with the condition of the roof of the Pine Creek Residential School. THE Beaver Merit Washer represents a combination of the highest washroom efficiency it is possible to obtain, with the lowest possible cost. We claim for this machine that it will do as much work, as good work and as quickly as the most expensive washer of equal size. The construction of this machine is a Monel Metal cylinder that is the last word in cylinder design, in a high grade Cypress tub, with every worth-while feature, such as dump outlets, added.

The Cylinder is the important part of the wash wheel and, if this embodies correct modern washing principles, the construction of the outer case is not so vital, and when to this cylinder is added the latest time-saving devices, the result is a washer equal, in the amount and quality of the work it will produce, to any machine made, no matter how high the price. The outer case of the Merit Washer is of all heart stock clear Cypress. This tub is good for from ten to fifteen years' service, and is cheaply renewable. With two such tubs the Merit Washer will last twenty-five to thirty years. The doors and doors fronts are of Monel Metal, making a handsome, easily-cleaned machine. The doors are of a new design, close-water tight and free from objectionable dripping over. The machine is equipped with one eight-inch Rapid Discharge Valve, operated by foot lever, and one or more Rear Inlets connected to one three-inch header. Any inlet valves up to three-inch may be used. Other equipment includes Auxiliary Soap Doors, Loading Apron, Thermometer, Water Level Indicator, Rapid Hand Turning Device and Cylinder Lock. Blue Siphon can be supplied as an extra. There is a new design flat bumper bar to protect the tub from damage by loading trucks.

The Cylinder is made entirely of Monel Metal. Absolutely no other material is used in its construction, and it is, therefore, entirely free from rust or verdigris. The cylinder is constructed after the manner of a high-pressure steel boiler or tank. The heavy end plates and partitions are flanged on the circumference and securely riveted to the cylindrical side sheets. In addition to this there are Monel stay bolts at each end. There are three large open back perforated lifting shelves so that the load never falls across them—an important point in net washing, as it tends to constrict the nets. The cylinder sheets are closely perforated with small double embossed holes. The embossing greatly increases the strength of the plates and makes a perfectly smooth inside to the cylinder. The small holes offer no chance for the smallest button or pin to get caught and torn off. The large number of perforations gives very rapid circulation. The cylinder doors are sliding, with neat removable locks. When closed, the doors are in positive engagement on all four sides, so that it is impossible for them to be distorted by the load.

The frames on which the machine is mounted are extra heavy rigid castings, and on them are mounted the bearings, which are roller type throughout. The gears are heavy, machine cut, with two-inch face, completely enclosed by gear guards. The trunions are extra heavy cast steel, operating in roller bearings. All bearings are always lubricated except the travel bearings for the reverse drum, which is run either with a deep oil well. In addition to being roller bearing, all bearings are adjustable so that wear may be taken up. A special arrangement of the gears ensures a quiet-running machine at all times.

We are confident that no other washer ever offered to the laundry trade combines so much in value and productiveness, at anywhere near the price, as the Merit Washer.

La Machine à Laver Beaver Merit représente une combinaison de la plus haute efficacité qu'il soit possible d'avoir dans une salle de buanderie, avec le coût le plus minime. Nous prétendons que cette machine fournira autant de travail, et tout aussi bon et aussi rapide que n'importe laquelle des machines à laver des plus coûteuses de même grandeur. La construction de cette machine est un cylindre en Métal Monel, c.à.d. le tout dernier mot en fait de construction et modèle de cylindre, dans une cuve de Cyprès de qualité supérieure, et la machine est également munie de tous les derniers perfectionnements, soupapes pour videment rapide, etc.

Le Cylindre est la partie importante de la roue de lavage et si ceci comprend les principes de lavage modernes corrects, la construction de la coque extérieure n'est pas si importante, et quand à ce cylindre sont joints les tout derniers perfectionnements pour économiser le temps et le labeur, l'on a comme résultat une machine à laver qui est équivalente, en ce qui concerne l'ouvrage et la qualité de l'ouvrage fourni, à n'importe quelle machine fabriquée, peu en importe le prix. En plus, la Machine à Laver Merit est une machine qui a une belle et agréable apparence, et qui fait honneur à n'importe quelle salle de buanderie.

(Tournez s. v. p.)

THE BEAVER LAUNDRY MACHINERY CO., LIMITED
MONTREAL - TORONTO
Le cylindre est construit selon le principe d'une cuve à haute pression. Les fortes plaques aux extrémités et les cloisons sont bridées à la circonférence et bien rivées aux tôles de côté cylindriques. En plus de cela il y a des entretoises en Monel allant d'un bout à l'autre. Il y a trois grandes traverses perforées, à dos ouvert, placées de sorte que jamais la charge ne pèse sur elles un point central pour le lavage avec filet car cela a tendance d'épargner les filets. Les tôles du cylindre sont perforées, avec les trous très rapprochés et doublées repoussées. Le repoussage augmente la solidité des tôles de beaucoup, et donne une surface parfaitement unie à l'intérieur du cylindre. Les petits trous n'offrent aucune occasion au plus petit bouton ou à une épingle de s'accrocher et d'être arrachés. Le grand nombre de trous donne une circulation très rapide. Les portes du cylindre sont à coulisse avec des serrures démontables ayant belle apparence. Quand elles sont fermées, les portes sont positivement engagées des quatre côtés, de sorte qu'il est impossible de les déformer par la charge.

Les cadres sur lesquels la machine est montée sont des pièces coulées extra-lourdes et rigides, et sur elles les paliers sont montés, qui eux sont du type à rouleaux de toute part. Les engrenages sont solides, coupés à la machine et ayant une surface de deux pouces, en plus ils sont complètement entourés de gardes-engrenages. Les tourillons sont en acier coulé extra-fort et fonctionnent sur des paliers à rouleaux. Tous les paliers sont à lubrification Alemite à l'exception du palier articulé pour l'entêteur de marche arrière qui lui est à bague de graissage avec un réservoir d'huile profond. En plus d'être des paliers à rouleaux, tous les paliers sont ajustables de façon à permettre de faire face à l'usure. Un arrangement spécial des engrenages assure que la machine fonctionnera sans bruit tout le temps.

Nous sommes persuadés qu'aucune autre machine à laver qui ait été offerte aux buanderies combine autant en valeur et productivité, à un prix se rapprochant un tant soit peu du notre, que la Machine à Laver Merk.

Further to our memorandum of November 16th in connection with the above, you are advised that we are in receipt of a letter and subsequent telegram from Mr. Gow in which he states that he contacted two firms with reference to quoting on the work at the above.

The firms contacted were Messrs Neale, Stothard and Chapman, of Brandon, Manitoba, and Frank Bumstead of Dauphin, Manitoba, both of whom have carried out satisfactory work for the Department on previous occasions.

Mr. Gow goes on to state that Messrs Neale, Stothard and Chapman have expressed willingness to quote when it is possible for their representative to visit the job. It may be inferred that Frank Bumstead is not in a position to quote, due to other commitments.

It is pointed out that this school is quite inaccessible in the winter months either by highway or railroad, and if an immediate inspection was considered necessary, it would involve the use of a snowmobile at considerable expense.

Although the work projected is necessary, it is considered that no actual emergency exists. Consequently we have requested Mr. Gow to advise the firm of Messrs Neale, Stothard and Chapman that he is prepared to receive their quotation as soon as it is possible for them to visit the school. He has also been requested to forward their price to this Division for consideration and analysis, as soon as it is received by him. At that time you will be further advised.

Memorandum

Re: Pine Creek Indian Residential School, Camperville, Manitoba

Your marginal notation dated May 28th, on a memorandum to you from the Director of Indian Affairs, requests a report dealing with a new roof for the above school.

You are advised in this connection as follows:

Subsequently to forwarding our memorandum of September 7th, 1948, to which Major MacKay refers, we obtained plans from Mr. Gow showing structural features, which had to be considered. These plans were carefully checked, and showed justification for recommendations contained in our previous memorandum of September 7th, 1948. Our recommendations based on Mr. Gow's report embraced work to the approximate value of $12,000.00.

Major MacKay replied under date of October 6th, 1948, stating that no funds had been provided in the Indian Affairs 1948-49 estimates for the work, but asked for a further recommendation before the 1949-50 estimates were prepared.

A memorandum to you under date of January 15th, 1949, stated that Mr. Gow's latest information showed the building to be safe for occupancy, and justified carrying out the proposed repairs. No comments or further instructions have been received from Indian Affairs, until the present.

We assume that Major MacKay's memorandum is authority for further action, and staff will be assigned to the project as soon as possible.

Memorandum

Re: Pine Creek Indian Residential School, Camperville, Manitoba

We are in receipt of a letter from Mr. Gow to which is attached a quotation from the Winnipeg Supply and Fuel Company in connection with the setting requirements for the horizontal return tubular high pressure boiler at the above.

The Winnipeg Supply and Fuel Company are specializing in the erection of plastic brick setting enclosing this type of boiler. This particular boiler was bricked in several years ago and the work failed to stand up. Since new setting is required it is proposed to take advantage of the latest and most up-to-date method of carrying out this work. With the plastic fire brick setting most of the individual fire bricks are eliminated, and a "Flibrico" plastic material having equal or superior refractory qualities is now in general use. This material has one important advantage over the individual fire bricks, in that any handy man can effect a repair and the repair can be bonded in satisfactorily. This is not true of settings which are wholly comprised of individual fire bricks.

We have examined the price quoted by the aforementioned firm and while somewhat higher than anticipated, it is felt that their proposition should be accepted. The only other alternative is to install a new steel fire box type boiler requiring no brick enclosure at a cost of approximately $3,500.00.

We are therefore recommending that this work be awarded to the Winnipeg Supply and Fuel Company on the basis of their quotation in the amount of $1,566.00. When the Indian Affairs Branch indicate their approval, we will instruct Mr. Gow to have the work started.

It is understood that a number of tubes in this boiler will have to be replaced. This work will cost an additional $300.00 to $400.00.

for Chief, Engineering and Construction Division.

Further reference to your letter of September 12, 1949, file No. 582-5 (EL) re Pine Creek Indian Residential School.

Please be advised the engine at the Pine Creek Residential School is old and has not enough power to handle the work it should. This matter was taken up last year. However, I felt that we had better wait and see if the power would go into the school this past summer. I have now been advised that there is a possibility of the power going as far as Winnipegosis this spring and probably further. Therefore, I do not feel that we should spend money on an engine at this time.

Fort Alexander School have a good 10 H.P. Lister engine that is not in use. This engine I understand is the property of the school - not the Department. However, I feel if you took the matter up with the Principal that he would be quite willing to let us have this engine. This engine could then be used at the Pine Creek School until such time as the power reaches that point.

R. S. Davis,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies.

Memorandum

Re: New Roof, Pine Creek Residential School, Camperville, Manitoba.

We are in receipt of a letter from Mr. Gow enclosing one tender only, which was supplied by the Bolton Construction Co. Ltd. of Winnipeg, a copy of which is attached. Also attached is a copy of Mr. Gow's covering letter which is self-explanatory.

It will be noted that Mr. Gow appears to be having considerable difficulty in obtaining additional tenders. In a project of this size where considerable urgency exists and many indeterminate factors are present, it seems advisable to have the work undertaken on a basis of cost plus a fixed fee.

The lump sum tender of $13,700.00 quoted by the Bolton Construction Co. Ltd. includes overhead and profit and is considered reasonable, but the actual cost may be reduced when work is commenced, since some material from the existing roof may be salvaged and re-used, the actual amount of which, neither the Bolton Construction Co. Ltd. nor our engineers can evaluate until work begins.

On the basis of cost plus a fixed fee we believe that the total cost of the work will be closer to our estimate of $12,000.00 than the price submitted, and it is recommended that approval for this action be obtained from Indian Affairs.

We would then be enabled to request Mr. Gow to obtain from the Bolton Construction Co. Ltd. of Winnipeg the amount of the fee for which they will undertake the work on that basis, and to commence the preparation of contract documents without further delay.

Chief, Engineering and Construction Division.

Enclos.

R.A. Gibson, Esq.,
Director,
Lands and Development Services Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.
Re: New roof and repairs - Pine Creek Indian Residential School, Camperville, Manitoba.

We are enclosing a quotation received from the Bolton Construction Company Limited, Contractors and Engineers of Winnipeg covering the new roof and repairs to the dormitories of the Pine Creek Indian Residential School near Camperville, Manitoba, prepared in accordance with your plans and specifications. You will note that the estimated amount is for the complete job, including over-head and profit and I am advised by Mr. Bolton that they have made the amount sufficiently high to permit of covering the many uncertainties that might tend to make the job quite expensive. You will also note that this Company suggest it would be more economical to do the work on a cost-plus fixed fee basis.

Following the receipt of your plans and specifications some several weeks ago, we forwarded copies of the same to supply dealers at Dauphin and Brandon with the request they contact builders in those areas and have them submit quotations or tenders to this office. We had no response to these communications. Apparently this is due to the uncertainty of how much existing material in the building could be used and also due to labour conditions.

This letter is being forwarded with the idea of giving you some criterion of the estimated cost of the project. It will be impossible to carry out the work during the present fiscal year and if it is your wish, we will endeavour to contact personally contractors in the Dauphin, Brandon and Winnipeg areas with a view to having more complete tenders submitted.

(Sgd) D.B. Gow

D.B. Gow,
District Engineer.

Re: New Roof, Pine Creek Residential School, Camperville, Manitoba.

We are in receipt of a letter from Mr. Gow enclosing one tender only, which was supplied by the Bolton Construction Co., Ltd. of Winnipeg, a copy of which is attached. Also attached is a copy of Mr. Gow's covering letter which is self-explanatory.

It will be noted that Mr. Gow appears to be having considerable difficulty in obtaining additional tenders. In a project of this size where considerable urgency exists and many indeterminate factors are present, it seems advisable to have the work undertaken on a basis of cost plus a fixed fee.

The lump sum tender of $13,700.00 quoted by the Bolton Construction Co., Ltd. includes overhead and profit and is considered reasonable, but the actual cost may be reduced when work is commenced, since some material from the existing roof may be salvaged and re-used, the actual amount of which, neither the Bolton Construction Co., Ltd. nor our engineers can evaluate until work begins.

On the basis of cost plus a fixed fee we believe that the total cost of the work will be closer to our estimate of $12,000.00 than the price submitted, and it is recommended that approval for this action be obtained from Indian Affairs.

New Roof - Pine Creek Residential School

Mr. Marcel Leperre, Ste. Rose du Lac, contractor has inspected the roof at Pine Creek Residential School, and submits a contract price on demolishing the old roof and reconstructing a new one, material and labour $31,800.00.

Mr. Leperre is using Plan #1 as a basis, although the trestle material in this plan is on the light side. All the plumbing on the third floor has to be replaced, new pipes, wash basins, and shower. The toilet will be remodelled, but will not have to be replaced.

Partitions have to be torn out and rebuilt; clothes, closets have to be torn out and replaced with new material. Three dead smoke stacks have to be levelled to the third floor and sealed. Four new ventilators must be constructed, two in each room. Windows at present are small, not waterproof, and are inadequate for lighting. It is considered that four groups of three windows in each room would be sufficient. Wiring will have to in conduit piping. Walls and ceiling will be insulated with rockwool pads finished with gyproc and two coats of paint. Roof is asphalt shingles, 210 lb. per sq. with No. 1 tarpaper.

It will not be possible to use any of the old material in the roof - the timbers are hand-hewn and are warped, and the plumbing is lead pipes.

On completion of the contract, debris will be cleared.

Mr. Leperre recommends that work be commenced on this project in March, so that considerable progress can be made before rain can be expected, and while the roads are hard for hauling.

(sgd) William Gowans

New Roof - Pine Creek Residential School, - Camperville, Manitoba.

With reference to our memorandum of the 17th February last, we are now in receipt of a letter from Mr. D.B. Gow dated the 25th February in which he advises as follows:

"We have had little success in interesting contractors in either the Dauphin or Brandon areas in submitting estimates or tenders on the proposed work. However, an estimate prepared by Mr. Marcel Leperre, Ste. Rose du Lac, Contractor, in answer to a request from this office, is enclosed. Mr. Leperre was asked to quote on the new specifications as outlined in your letter of February 18 and his estimate, in comparison with that of the Bolton Construction Company at Winnipeg, appears quite high.

We are also enclosing copy of a letter which was forwarded by the Superintendent of the Indian Agency at Dauphin to his Head Office at Ottawa under date of February 11 relating to a tender submitted by Mr. Marcel Leperre covering work which was considered necessary in connection with repairs to roof. This communication is forwarded for your information only."

We enclose copies of the above mentioned letter from William Gowans, Superintendent Indian Agency for your information.

Plans and specifications were prepared by this Service and sent Mr. Gow for the purpose of obtaining tenders for the above work. The tenders so far submitted are as follows:

Bolton Construction Company Limited, Winnipeg, Manitoba.
dated the 3rd December, 1949........$13,700.00

Marcel Leperre, Ste. Rose du Lac, Manitoba. dated the 22nd February, 1950.....................$25,645.00

A. Freiheit, Dauphin, Manitoba
dated the 22nd February, 1950.......$28,825.00

the latter two forwarded by the Superintendent of the Indian Agency at Dauphin.
It may be that Mr. Gowans has taken advantage of this opportunity to have included in the two latter tenders all the repairs and new work he would like to have done on the top storey of this school as indicated in his letter to which reference has been made above.

We are writing Mr. Gow to have the Bolton Construction Company review their tender, since some time has elapsed since it was submitted, and it is felt desirable to be quite sure that this Company has taken into consideration all items that may enter into the cost of this work.

We feel that the tenders of Leperre and Freihert are too high and not based on our drawings and specifications.

OTTAWA, Ont.

New Roof - Pine Creek Indian Residential School

Mr. Marcel Leperre, Ste. Rose du Lac, contractor, has inspected the roof at Pine Creek Residential School and submits a contract price on demolishing the old roof and reconstructing a new one, material and labour $31,800.00.

Mr. Leperre is using Plan #1 as a basis, although the trestle material in this plan is on the light side. All the plumbing on the third floor has to be replaced, new pipes, wash basins and shower. The toilet will be remodelled, but will not have to be replaced.

Partitions have to be torn out and rebuilt; clothes closets have to be torn out and replaced with new material. Three dead smoke stacks have to be levelled to the third floor and sealed. Four new ventilators must be constructed; two in each room. Windows at present are small, not waterproof, and are inadequate for lighting. It is considered that four groups of three windows in each room would be sufficient. Wiring will have to be in conduit piping. Walls and ceiling will be insulated with rockwool pads, finished with gyproc and two coats of paint. Roof is asphalt shingles, 210 lb. per square with No. 1 tarpaper.

It will not be possible to use any of the old material in the roof - the timbers are hand-hewn and are warped, and the plumbing is lead pipes. On completion of the contract, debris will be cleared.

Mr. Leperre recommends that work be commenced on this project in March so that considerable progress can be made before rain can be expected and while the roads are hard for hauling.

(Signed) "William Gowans",
Supt. Indian Agency.

Re: Pine Creek Indian Residential School

In your letter of June 27th, 1949, file 214-11 ARC, you recommended that funds be provided for the erection of a new barn at the above school. We obtained an amount of $5,000.00 in the Supplementary Estimates 1949-50, and have bought materials at an approximate cost of $5,800.00.

Please let me know as soon as possible what type of barn the school management wishes to erect, and also the cost of the labour. It is presumed that the school management will provide some of the labour at least without cost to the Department. However, if it is necessary to engage a foreman, you should submit the name and address of the person whom it is intended to employ, in order that we can obtain the Minister's approval.

In your letter of June 27th, 1949, you mentioned that the cost of the barn would be approximately $11,000.00. As we have already expended $5,800.00, it is presumed that the labour will not exceed $5,200.00. Of course, if the school management provide some of the labour free of charge, the cost of labour should be less than the amount stated.

MEMORANDUM FOR THE DIRECTOR

NEW ROOF - PINE CREEK RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL,
CAMPERVILLE, MANITOBA.

With reference to our memorandum of the 15th of March relative to the above, it is proposed to transfer responsibility for the proposed work from Mr. D.B. Gow to Supervising Engineer W.W. Perrie. Before sending instructions to Mr. Perrie it is felt advisable to review the situation for Indian Affairs and await their comments as to what procedure they may desire us to follow.

Little success has been reported in interesting contractors in either the Dauphin or Brandon areas in submitting lump sum tenders on the work.

We have received however, the following:

Bolton Construction Company,
1206 Wolseley Avenue,
Winnipeg, Manitoba.
October 5 and December 3, 1949,
approximate estimate including
a fixed fee of $1,400.00 . . . . . $13,700.00

Marcel Leperre, Esq.,
Ste. Rose du Lac, Manitoba.
dated 22nd February, 1950 . . . . . $25,645.00

A. Freihheit, Esq.,
Dauphin, Manitoba.
dated 22nd February, 1950 . . . . . $28,825.00

the latter two forwarded by Superintendent Gowans of the Indian Agency at Dauphin. It appears that Mr. Gowans has taken advantage of this opportunity to have included in the latter two tenders, all the required alterations and new work he would like to have done to the top storey of this school. We feel that the tenders of Laperre and Freihheit are too high and are not based entirely on our drawings and specifications while the price submitted by the Bolton Construction Company is an approximate estimate only.

From the foregoing, it may be seen that the obtaining of tenders has not been altogether satisfactory, but with improved weather conditions it should be possible for contractors to visit the site and examine the roof and dormitories and thus be able to prepare bona fide tenders.

The work may have to be undertaken on a basis of cost plus a fixed fee, but the possibility of obtaining lump sum tenders should be given consideration.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6271, file 582-5, part 10)
The history of this institution shows that the interior floor construction due to changes by the school personnel has caused considerable concern in the past; bearing partitions and columns having been removed which resulted in the floors sagging to an alarming extent. Columns and beams were re-introduced which prevented further deflection but left the floors very uneven. It was only after considerable study of the plans and of various reports that the building was passed as safe for occupancy and the opinion reached that the life expectancy of the structure warranted the expenditure required for a new roof.

The roof has been leaking for several years and is reported to be structurally unsound and in need of replacement. As pointed out in a preceding paragraph, the Indian Superintendent appears to have in mind a considerable amount of repair work including toilets, plumbing, electric lighting, new windows, removal of partitions, etc., the extent or value of which we are not in a position to assess until an inspection is made. When such an inspection is made, this item will be noted and an estimate prepared for consideration by Indian Affairs, but the replacement of the roof should receive priority over any other factors unless the Indian Affairs Branch wish to amplify their original proposal to this Service, and have funds for the purpose.

We will appreciate receiving instructions on the matter.

Chief.

Re- Pine Creek Indian Residential School.

I beg to submit for the Departments consideration our Requisition for Beds and Mattresses for the above mentioned school.

On my last visit to that school April 29th 1950 I requested the Sister Superior to show me the beds and mattresses, these I checked personally with Sister Superior and two other Sisters and the condition of 47 mattresses was found to be very bad, most of them had been wetted over a long period others were so poor that the outside cover of the mattresses were falling apart.

This condition was never brought to my attention, however it has been known to Sister Superior for the last four years, the good Sisters have been trying to rebuild and repair the mattresses for several years now.

Re: Pine Creek Indian Residential School

We are in receipt of a letter from Superintendent Gowans, enclosing the attached requisition for beds and mattresses to be supplied to the Pine Creek Residential School. It is not usual for so many beds to go out of condition at the same time. When forwarding the requisition, Mr. Gowans wrote as follows:

"The 103 beds requested are to replace the old beds, most all of which the springs are broken in many places. Some of them have been restrung with clothes wire, and others have been repaired with electric wire. These beds are of a type that one cannot replace the spring, as the spring and frame are all in one. Many of them are without casters, and I feel that the time has come when they should be replaced. The old beds could be given to many families on the reserve where I am sure they would be appreciated."

If the beds are in as bad a condition as Mr. Gowans states, I doubt if they would be of much value to anyone on the reserve. Purchase of the beds and mattresses requested will involve a considerable sum of money, and before making any decision in the matter, we would appreciate your comments.

Dear Sir:

Re: Roof, Pine Creek School - Camperville, Man.

Arriving in Winnipeg on Wednesday Aug. 16th, I met Mr. Davis and Mr. Krawchuk and arranged to leave for Camperville by car on the following day. Copies of plans, specifications and bills of materials had been received by Mr. Davis from Mr. Perrie.

On Thursday Aug. 17th Mr. Krawchuk and I arrived at the school in the late evening. As the Principal was away on holiday we were not able to obtain any details of the structural changes made in the school since it was originally built although we were told that it was about 50 years old.

The roof was examined the next day and numerous measurements were taken. The present trusses consisting of two leaves of 2 x 6 with two inch pack pieces for both top and bottom chords with diagonal webs are spaced at about 15' 6" centres. They appear to be of tamarack timber which is well preserved. The middle of each lower chord rests on posts of double 2 x 6 with 2 inch pack pieces, which posts also continue through vertically to the ridge. The trusses do not appear to swing and thus really consist of four braced beams in each case. Purlins of 2 x 6 dapped two inches under the upper chords carry the intermediate 2 x 4 rafters spaced about 20 to 22 inches on centres.

The roof sags both longitudinally and laterally as also does the dormitory ceiling. Numerous truss type braces have been recently placed in the attic to help both the trusses and the ceiling joists to carry their loads. The pitch of the roof is about one quarter. It would seem advisable to prevent the accumulation of a heavy snow load while the roof is in its present condition.

While the timbers visible in the attic appear to be in good condition it would seem necessary to rebuild the roof according to the new design to remedy structural defects and provide a fireproof covering to the weather.

Ltd. and from Marcel Lepere, offering to undertake the work on a basis of cost plus a fixed fee are also attached.

4. I am also attaching copy of a letter received from Mr. R.S. Davis in which he mentions Arlington Builders, Winnipeg, as the only firm other than those mentioned above that might be interested in tendering on this work. Mr. Davis also states that although Mr. Krawchuk would not be able to remain continually on the job during its progress he has in mind a suitable foreman that might be engaged to carry on with the work under Mr. Krawchuk's supervision.

October 4, 1938.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 26th ultimo enclosing letter received from Sister Patricia Fuller, teacher of the Waterhen River Indian Day School.

As far as this Branch is aware no agreement similar to that suggested in Sister Fuller's letter has been made.

On Reserves where day schools are situated the Department considers that parents who are able to provide for the maintenance of their children should be encouraged to have the children attend the day school.

From the correspondence forwarded with your letter it would appear that the children of Albert Nepinak who have been regularly admitted to the Pine Creek Residential School have not yet been officially discharged. If the Principal of the Pine Creek School has no objection the Department would favourably consider granting the discharge of the Nepinak children from the Pine Creek School on the understanding that they would regularly attend the Waterhen River Day School. If, however, the Principal requires these children it is considered that they should be returned to Pine Creek.

Yours truly,

Mr. J. Waite, Indian Agent,
Portage la Prairie.

Dear Sir,

On the occasion of your last visit at Pine Creek School, The Indian Inspector Mr. Hamilton, mentioned that Albert McKay should be in school. We have given attention to his case, for which Application Forms are hereby enclosed and forwarded to your office.

Doctor Medd told us that he had no objection to the admission of this boy in our school as long as it was on the Indian Inspector's recommendation; although he was afraid that such case might be a source of trouble for the authorities of the school in case of accident, the boy having rickets.

We have advised the parents, of the child's state of health, and promised them to do our utmost to avoid accidents, but in case same would happen we would not like to be blamed for it. They agreed to put the child in school. We were glad to accept him.

Also enclosed Application for Admission of Norman Comtois and Helen Kakewash. Helen, being an orphan was accepted under age.

Very truly yours,

C. Ruest, O.M.I.

Ottawa,
February 27, 1940.

Reverend Sir:

A review of the December quarter return of the Pine Creek Indian Residential School shows that pupil No. 0190, Mary J. Clearsky, is over the age of 16.

No application for retaining this girl in your school appears to have been received and in this connection I wish to direct your attention to circular letter of July 21, 1939, a copy of which is enclosed.

As pointed out in the circular letter the Department realizes that frequently there are reasons for keeping certain children after they reach the age of 16 but at the same time the consent of the Superintendent General (Minister) must be obtained.

I may add that in the past the Department has been favourably disposed to allowing certain pupils, especially girls, to remain in residential schools after they reach the age of 16 if good reasons for such action are given by the Principal and approved by the Indian Agent. However, in view of the fact that the number of children of school age is apparently increasing and the further consideration that due to the conditions now confronting us there is no immediate prospect of our securing funds to provide increased pupilage at Indian residential schools, it is considered that in future it will be necessary to adhere more strictly to the provision of the Indian Act requiring discharge of pupils at 16 years of age.

Rev. C. Ruest, O.M.I.,
Principal,
Pine Creek Indian Residential School,
Camperville, Man.
I feel you will agree with me that it is not fair to deprive children of education simply because the accommodation that might be available for them in a residential school is being used by those who have had the advantage of residential school training for some years and who have reached the age of 16 years.

Until further advised you should make arrangements for the discharge of pupils when they reach the age of 16 unless there are some very exceptional circumstances and in this event full particulars should be given to the Department and our permission obtained before such pupils reach the age of 16.

With the above in mind I desire to hear from you at the earliest possible date stating the date on which the pupil mentioned in the first part of this letter can be discharged from your school.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Sir,

Re: 126-1-10

I beg to acknowledge receipt of Department letter dated the 28th instant with reference to the admission of the Kematch children, No. 140 Shoal River Reserve. There are seven paid on this ticket, man, woman, two boys and three girls. One boy and two girls are in the school at the present time, leaving a girl (Bella) two years and a boy (Jim) eight months. I am informed that these children were taken away from the reserve by their mother and are residing with her. I have tried to ascertain if the parents are now living together again without success up to this time. The mails to Shoal River Reserve have been stopped temporary on account of ice conditions and it will not be possible to visit this reserve until the ice goes out of Lake Winnipegosiss.

During my last visit to the Shoal River Reserve, Kematch was living with another woman, his wife had left previously for Duck Bay taking the children with her. The older children were placed in the school, - a letter from the Rev. Principal attached. The illicit union was broken up and the man sent to Duck Bay to find his wife and family and bring them back to the reserve. The man left the Shoal River reserve with this intention, fished in the vicinity of Duck Bay until the end of the fishing season to obtain sufficient funds to enable him to return home and to date I have received no advice as to his return to Shoal River. It is not unlikely that the man will trap in the area between Camperville and Pelican Lake, returning to the reserve when the lake breaks up. I have written the reserve for further information and as soon as
this is received, the Department will be duly advised.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa.

Manitoba Sept. 24th, 1940.

Lawrence CATCHWAY, Herbert ST. PAUL, Edmond HEPINAK, and Roland ROULETTE, Camperville Indian Res. School, Truants from Camperville Indian Res. School.

15-9-40.

1. At 1:00 p.m., this date Father Ruest, Principal of the Camperville Indian Res. School, called at this Detachment to inform that the four above named had run away from School the previous afternoon, he stated he made inquiries along the road enroute to Winnipegosis and learned that these boys were seen about 3 miles from Winnipegosis about 10:00 a.m., same date and were proceeding South. Ruest continued his patrol to Port River and Dauphin while the writer commenced local enquiries.

2. At 5:30 p.m., same date the writer located two of these boys in the Village and as a result the two remaining boys were located in the bush West of the Village where they were in hiding. All four boys were taken into custody and as they had not eaten all day they were fed before proceeding to Camperville.

3. At 7:30 p.m., same date the writer left per P.C. Code #1670 and patrolled to Camperville where these four boys were handed over to Father Poulette of the Indian Res. School.

Patrol returned at 11:30 p.m., same date.

DAUPHIN, October 11th, 1940.

R. A. Hoey, Esq.,
Director of Education,
Indian Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
OTTAWA.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

Re: Roland Roulette,

The above is an orphan boy, ten years of age, who has been in the Camperville Mission School for the past five years. The grandfather of this child, who is his guardian, was in to see me today with advice that he fears unless this boy is removed from this school, something serious may happen to the child. It appears that the boy suffers from a kidney disorder which causes him to urinate during the night and instead of the child being treated medically for the trouble, he is whipped. This whipping and other forms of punishment, I am informed, has been going on for some considerable time. Just recently the boy ran away from the school and was found 30 miles from the village of Camperville.

The grandfather, Mr. McAuley, lives at Crane River, Manitoba, an Indian reservation in the Dauphin constituency and is not only willing, but anxious to take the boy, give him a home and education. I know Mr. McAuley very well. His home is about 200 yards from a fairly good public school, and I can see no reason whatsoever why the child's education would not be just as well taken care of at Crane River, and where he would be with his own relatives who would
have a more sympathetic understanding of his physical weakness and do something about having it corrected. I am not familiar with the routine requirements in affecting a transfer of a child from a Mission School to a public school, but I have no hesitation at all in assuring you that the child would be well taken care of if returned to his grandparents, Mr. and Mrs. C. McAuley at Crane River, Manitoba.

I would appreciate your looking into this matter at your early convenience and if a transfer is to be affected, it would be well to do so before winter sets in.

Thanking you in advance, I remain,

Yours very truly,

WJW/RF.

J. Ward, M.P.

Dear Sir,

Re Roland Roulette.

I am sorry that you have this inconvenience. I am pleased to give you all the information that I can so you can apportion any blame and suggest proper remedies.

The boy's condition-

He is eleven years old—weighs 68 lbs and is in good physical condition. Parents dead. He wets bed at times—His grandfather told him he would grow out of this—he has not just done so. In my opinion a long foreskin is causing some irritation and this may be a part cause and in my opinion a circumcision should be done. This will help to remedy his condition to a certain extent. There is no kidney trouble. Whipping is not a cure and he is not whipped for this condition. The Father in charge of this school very rarely if ever approves of whipping. The Sister Superior never whipped this boy ever. The boy was whipped once by his teacher—he said he was bad and that the teacher did not whip him very hard.

The boy left school because he was lonesome—he told me so and he also told Constable Hanna the same. This boy left school with three other boys—came to Winnipegosis—were picked up by Constable Hanna—given food and taken back to school. No boy left school because of whippings—Their reason was that they...
were lonesome. This boy had not been whipped this term before he ran away. The bed wetting and whipping received the grandfather evidently knew about and had opportunities to discuss this with the Father in charge but evidently had not done so. I believe the grandfather has thought that something terrible must have happened to cause the boys to run away. There is no foundation for this supposition.

The boys were lonesome. There were also some weddings back home and that suggested good times for a day or two.

The solution.

The boy is a fine boy. He tells me he does not want me to send him home to stay but would like me to send him home when he is lonesome. He wants to go to school till he is fourteen years old. That's where he should be.

The guardian should give permission for circumcision which will help him some. I think, Mr Hoey, you have been troubled by a grandfather who knows you do not know him otherwise he would likely have reported to the Indian Agent. I do not know this man - I would like to have had a talk with him.

I trust I have given you sufficient information for the proper disposal of this case.

Yours Sincerely

A.B.Medd

Sir,

Re: 126-1-10

I beg to acknowledge receipt of Department letter dated the 24th ultimo in connection with Roland Roulette, No. 219 Sandy Bay Band, a pupil of the Pine Creek Indian Residential School.

In reporting on the home condition of the grandparents, I wish to state that they are probably as good as the average half-breed family living in the vicinity of the Crane River Reserve. Living is every bit as precarious. I am well acquainted with the grandfather, (Mr. McAuley) and am positive from various contacts with this man that the welfare of his grandchild is not the main consideration. This boy has now a few dollars in the bank at Ottawa and if the boy was allowed home, this money would be requested and in a short time further requests would be made for a monthly allowance for the keep of the boy. The funding of the boy's money has been a source of annoyance to Mr. McAuley, who considers this money his because he is the boy's guardian.

I do not know what form Doctor Medd's report to the Department will take. I do wish to state, however, that I am certain the boy was never whipped for bed wetting. Neither the Principal nor the Sister Superior are the kind of persons who would abuse a child for a physical ailment. The Sister Superior is a motherly woman of wide experience whom the children love. The feeling of the children for the superiors is obvious as soon as one enters the school. I am positive the grandfather wants this boy only to use as a lever to obtain, from the Department, benefits for his own use.

The Secretary,

Dear Sir,

As I have had a bad cough for over two years and is getting worse which now affects my strength also my wind and therefore I am unable to do my work and make my living properly. I am not able to do any copying nor heavy lifting. Dr Sharman Burgess whom has examined me and told me I had chest trouble.

Now my reason for writing is this. I have a boy at Pine Creek Indian Residential School, Comperville Man. Who will be fifteen this coming June 17th. I would be very thankful if you could discharge this boy from school right away and let him come home & work for me. I do not like the idea of having to be one the returned from the Dept. As I have fine good horses which I could put to use if I had someone with me. I have not the money to hire a man steady. Also I have tried to make a go of it myself but I am unable to do so. I am getting rather a bit discouraged and weak.

Indian Affairs Branch

Ottawa

Regarding your letter No.126-1-10 of Feb.1st concerning the request of Charlie Shingoose of the Waywayseecappo Band, to have his son discharged from Pine Creek Residential school.

This man has chest trouble, and about two months ago Dr Sharman of Anglesville diagnosed his trouble as a septic condition in the base of the lung, but recommending an X-ray to confirm his diagnosis. All Shingoose has to do is to arrange to go to Russell with Dr. Sharman some day and have an X-ray taken, and he has not yet done so, though I advised him to do so weeks ago. It is quite possible that if that diagnosis is correct, hospital treatment would affect a cure. The boy Michael, has had very little education and I do not recommend his discharge from school until his father takes steps to be X-rayed, and if necessary treatment. If that is done and he actually requires the boy then, which is quite possible, his discharge could be arranged.

A.G. Smith  
Indian Agent

Dear Sir:

I have to report that Donald Catheway has been removed by his parents from the above Day School, and entered in the Pine Creek Residential School, along with a younger sister, Sarah Jane Catcheway, age 7 years.

This was done without my knowledge and consent. The putting of these children into the Residential School is not for educational, financial or sickness reasons, but entirely for immoral reasons.

Mrs. Alex Catcheway has for several years made and sold home-brew. Repeatedly quarrelled with her husband to the extent of endeavoring to separate from him.

The husband, of course, is not blameless. He also drinks and is not a good provider, although a good hunter. He spends too much money in gambling. This past Summer and again at the present time, he gave his wife to his brother. I understand that she is still living with this man, while her husband is elsewhere.

The putting away of the children is solely to facilitate their immoral living.

Mrs. Catcheway claims she is too sick to keep her children. Dr. Medd has repeatedly asserted that there is nothing wrong with her. She also states that her husband does not provide for his family. There is no reason for his not doing so.

Rev. Father C. Huest, O.M.I., Principal of the Pine Creek School, is willing to return these children at my request. But I feel it is for the Department to take the Decision.

If I request their return the mother will worry me constantly with her complaints of being too sick to care for them, and being unable to support them. My knowledge that she is being quite untruthful will not prevent the continuous annoyance.
On the other hand, if I let these children go, I shall not be in a position to refuse others. I have another healthy young mother who, at intervals, declares that her little children are too much trouble and wishes to put them away.

It would seem to be a new fashion for young parents to give away their children and partners as soon as possible.

I was not aware that the Indian Treaty agreed to completely raise all children of healthy Indians. This would appear unreasonable to the taxpayers.

I feel that by allowing children under such circumstances to enter a Residential School, we are encouraging parents in their immoral living. Besides these two cases we have another couple living together unmarried and raising children.

It maybe argued that such homes are unfit for children. True; but it seems to me that to relieve such parents of all responsibilities of raising their families we are not only encouraging them, but are actually assisting them in their unlawful way of life.

If such conditions are permitted to continue, the moral effect on the younger generation will eventually be disastrous. Conditions among the young folks are already bad.

Before removing Donald Catcheway's name from my school register I shall respectfully await the Department's decision in the case.

I remain yours respectfully,

Sister Patricia, T. O. S. F.
Teacher.
Mr. [illegible] -

Would like you to read this letter and return. I thought we should advise her that while we delay certain actions of the present time at the same time we are responsible for assuring the welfare of the children.

Ottawa,
December 18, 1944.

Dear Sister:

I have your letter of the 2nd instant with reference to placing the two Catcheway children in the Pine Creek Residential School. I have carefully considered your letter and I feel it is unnecessary for me to state that the officials deeply deplore the action of some of the parents in neglecting their children in the manner mentioned in your letter. However, the officials of this Division have always felt that in spite of what the parents may do it is our duty to provide for the best interests of the children. With this in mind we feel that if either or both parents are not carrying out their duty it is, in most cases at least, in the best interests of the children to place them in a residential school where they will receive the care that they require.

I wish to take this opportunity of extending to you my best wishes for Christmas and the New Year.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Sister Patricia, T.O.S.F.,
